title:
Exploiting Spatial and Temporal Correlations in Massive MIMO Systems
  Over Non-Stationary Aging Channels

sections.text:
#### Abstract

This work investigates a multi-user, multi-antenna uplink wireless system, where multiple users transmit signals to a base station. Previous research has explored the potential for linear growth in spectral efficiency by employing multiple transmit and receive antennas. This gain depends on the quality of channel state information and uncorrelated antennas. However, spatial correlations, arising from closely-spaced antennas, and channel aging effects, stemming from the difference between the channel at pilot and data time instances, can substantially counteract these benefits and degrade the transmission rate, especially in non-stationary environments. To address these challenges, this work introduces a real-time beamforming framework to compensate for the spatial correlation effect. A channel estimation scheme is then developed, leveraging temporal channel correlations and considering mobile device velocity and antenna spacing. Subsequently, an expression approximating the average spectral efficiency is obtained, dependent on pilot spacing, pilot and data powers, and beamforming vectors. By maximizing this expression, optimal parameters are identified. Numerical results reveal the effectiveness of the proposed approach compared to prior works. Moreover, optimal pilot spacing remains unaffected by interference components such as path loss and the velocity of interference users. The impact of interference components also diminishes with an increasing number of transmit antennas.


Index terms- Beamforming, channel aging, multi-user MIMO, multiple antennas, non-stationary channels, pilot spacing, spectral efficiency

## I. INTRODUCTION

In the past two decades, the integration of multiple antennas at both the transmitter and receiver nodes has emerged as a crucial advancement, offering significant advantages in achieving high spectral efficiency (SE) [1]-[7]. Notably, massive multiple input multiple output (MIMO) technology, characterized by a substantial number of antennas at the base station (BS), enhances the coverage and SE in the uplink of wireless communications. The studies by [1], [2] highlight a linear growth in ergodic capacity with the number of transmit antennas compared to the single transmit antenna case, and this linear gain is achieved in high signal-to-interference-plus-noise ratio (SINR) regimes with uncorrelated transmit and receive antennas and when perfect channel state information at the transmitter (CSIT) is available [7]-[9].

Furthermore, the correlation between transmit antennas in uplink communications due to insufficient antenna spacing in small mobile devices can substantially degrade the SE. This necessitates optimal signal design strategies at the transmitter. Beamforming, a scalar coding strategy where the transmit covariance matrix is unit-rank, has been identified as one solution. In beamforming, the symbol stream undergoes coding and multiplication by different coefficients at each antenna before transmission. In the context of multi-user multiple input multiple output (MU-MIMO), studies such as [1] demonstrate that user-specific beamforming achieves the sum-capacity with partial channel side information, as discussed by [4], [10].

In a single-antenna uplink scenario within a multi-cellular environment, works such as [8], [11], [12] suggest that linear decoders and precoders behave nearly optimally. Notably, the impact of intra-cell interference diminishes as the number of BS antennas becomes sufficiently large. Additionally, some studies have derived deterministic approximations of SINR for uplink scenarios with maximum ratio combining (MRC) and minimum mean squared error (MMSE) receivers under blockfading channel assumptions, assuming that the number of BS antennas and users tend to infinity at the same rate.

While the advantages highlighted in the mentioned studies concerning multiple antennas are evident, these benefits depend critically on the perfect knowledge of the channel at the transmitter, emphasizing the crucial role of CSIT as noted in [7].

However, existing models often assume block-fading, where the channel remains constant during training and data times, a condition that may not hold in practice, particularly in non-stationary wireless channels as modeled in [13]-[20]. Furthermore, due to the relative movement of mobile users in wireless communications, delayed CSIT, known as channel aging, may occur, resulting from changes in the channel at pilot and data time slots. Neglecting this channel aging effect can negatively impact the capacity of massive MU-MIMO systems, motivating several papers to leverage temporal correlation structures to improve channel estimates [21]-[30].

Studies exploring the impact of channel aging, such as [25], [29], [30], have introduced closed-form expressions for the deterministic equivalent SINR under channel aging, considering single input multiple output (SIMO) uplink and multiple input single output (MISO) downlink scenarios. The inherent challenges of pilot spacing and frame size dimensioning, discussed in [29], [31], [32], highlight the need to balance the resources for channel state information at the receiver (CSIR) acquisition and communication in the presence of channel aging, considering power budgets and evolving channel characteristics.

Motivated by these insights and utilizing tools from ran-

dom matrix theory [33], this paper introduces an asymptotically tight deterministic expression for the average SE in the MU-MIMO scenario, featuring multiple antennas at both uplink users and the BS. The proposed framework capitalizes on the temporal dynamics of the channel within a multi-user context, emphasizing the importance of tailored CSIT acquisition for MIMO systems operating over non-stationary wireless channels. Specifically, the emphasis lies in the uplink of a MU-MIMO system, where each user has multiple antennas in a non-stationary aging channel. Delving into the intricate tradeoffs related to imperfect channel knowledge, temporal correlation, and channel aging contributes to a holistic understanding of MIMO system performance in dynamic (and specifically non-stationary) wireless environments. Furthermore, the paper establishes a real-time beamforming framework to harness the evolving nature of both spatial and temporal correlations. Numerical experiments show the efficacy of the proposed approach in exploiting both spatial and temporal correlations.

## A. Contributions and Key Differences with Prior Works

We summarize the contributions of this paper in the following list:

1) Deterministic spectral efficiency in MU-MIMO systems: We propose a novel, explicit deterministic expression that accurately characterizes the expected spectral efficiency in multi-user MIMO (MU-MIMO) systems with multiple antennas. Unlike previous works that rely on first-order deterministic equivalent approximations, such as those in [8], [29], [30], [34]-[38], or the use-and-then-forget (UTF) bounds in [39]-[41], our proposed bound takes into account second-order determinist expressions that provides significantly improved accuracy. This bound remains precise across a broad range of scenarios, including both sub-6 GHz and millimeterwave (mm-wave) channels, and is particularly effective as the number of BS antennas increases. Moreover, the number of users can be even much larger that the number of BS antennas. The theoretical validity of our approach is supported by mathematical analysis and extensive numerical simulations, demonstrating its superiority over existing methods in predicting the expected spectral efficiency.
2) Optimal beamforming design for enhanced spectral efficiency: To leverage the advantages of employing multiple antennas at the transmitter, we investigate a beamforming vector designed to reshape the data symbols. The determination of optimal beamforming vectors involves maximizing the per-slot deterministic spectral efficiency. We find a closed-form relation for the optimal real-time deterministic beamformer. The utilization of these optimal beamformers significantly enhances the resulting deterministic equivalent spectral efficiency. This differs from [42], which proposes a random beamforming approach.
3) Optimal frame design and power allocation: We propose an optimization framework aimed at maximizing the proposed deterministic-equivalent averaged spectral efficiency while satisfying some power constraints. This
endeavor involves identifying optimal values for parameters such as the number of frames, frame sizes, pilot and data powers.
4) Proposing a new algorithm for resource optimization By utilizing an alternative optimization technique and employing steepest ascent, we introduce an effective algorithm for the optimization of transmitter parameters, including pilot spacing, pilot and data powers, and beamformers.
5) Transmitter-centric optimization approach: Our findings indicate that interference components, such as path loss and Doppler frequencies, do not exert an influence on the deterministic equivalent spectral efficiency when a large number of transmit antennas are employed. Additionally, interference components do not impact the optimal frame design, suggesting that all optimization tasks related to frame design can be performed at the transmitter. This eliminates the necessity of transmitting optimal parameters through feedback control loops from the receiver to the transmitter, as discussed in [25], [29]. In scenarios without incorporating transmit beamforming design and with single-antenna users, as discussed in [30], interference may adversely affect the deterministic spectral efficiency. While previous works, including [29], [31], [32], advocate for achieving optimal pilot spacing at the receiver side and transmitting optimal values to the transmitter through feedback or control loops, it is essential to acknowledge that this approach may waste resources and make delays leading to the potential reduction in spectral efficiency.
6) Closed-form expressions for the correlation matrix in MIMO channels: We formulate explicit closed-form expressions for the correlation matrix needed for MIMO channels. Our findings demonstrate that these expressions are accessible in practical non-stationary MIMO time-varying environments. Specifically, in stationary environments, the derived formulas explicitly rely on the spacing between transmit and receive antenna elements, as well as the velocity of users.

## B. Outline

The paper is organized as follows. In Section II, we state the considered model and assumptions for the channel provided in Section II-A and for the uplink pilot and data model provided in Section II-B. Section III outlines the roadmap for obtaining the instantaneous SINR and introduces an alternative deterministic expression, leveraging random matrix theory to approximate the random SINR. In Section III, we propose a novel optimization problem that takes into account this deterministic SE and finds the optimal values of beamforming vectors, frame sizes, number of frames and pilot and data powers. Moreover, we propose a heuristic algorithm to find the optimal values of frame size, number of frames and pilot and data powers. Finally, the paper is concluded in Section V.

## C. Notation

$\mathbf{I}_{N}$ denotes the identity matrix of size $N$. vec stands for the column stacking vector operator that transforms a matrix

$\mathbf{X} \in \mathbb{C}^{M \times N}$ into its vectorized version $\mathbf{x} \triangleq \boldsymbol{\operatorname { v e c }}(\mathbf{X}) \in \mathbb{C}^{M N \times 1}$. The cross covariance matrix between vectors $\mathbf{x}$ and $\mathbf{y}$ is shown by $\mathbf{C}_{\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y}} \triangleq \mathrm{E}\left[(\mathbf{x}-\mathrm{E}[\mathbf{x}])(\mathbf{y}-\mathrm{E}[\mathbf{y}])^{\mathrm{H}}\right]$. The auto-covariance of a random vector $\mathbf{x}$ is shown by $\mathbf{C}_{\mathbf{x}} \triangleq \mathrm{E}\left\{(\mathbf{x}-\mathrm{E}[\mathbf{x}])(\mathbf{x}-\mathrm{E}[\mathbf{x}])^{\mathrm{H}}\right\}$. $\mathbf{e}_{k} \in \mathbb{R}^{N}$ refers to a vector that has all components equal to zero except for the $k$-th component. $\mathbf{1}_{N} \in \mathbb{R}^{N \times 1}$ is an all-one vector of size $N . j \triangleq \sqrt{-1}$ is the imaginary unit. $\lambda_{\max }(\mathbf{A})$ stands for the maximum eigenvalue of the matrix $\mathbf{A} .[\mathbf{A}]_{k, l}$ is used for the $(k, l)$-th element of the matrix $\mathbf{A} . J_{0}(\cdot)$ is the zeroth-order Bessel function of the first kind and is defined as $J_{0}(x) \triangleq \frac{1}{2 \pi} \int_{-\pi}^{\pi} \mathrm{e}^{-j x \sin (t)} \mathrm{d} t . \gamma \xrightarrow{\mathrm{P}} \gamma^{\gamma}$ means that $\gamma$ converges in probability to $\gamma^{\gamma}$, i.e. $\mathrm{P}\left[\left|\gamma-\gamma^{\gamma}\right|>\epsilon\right]=0 \forall \epsilon>0 . \mu_{n} \xrightarrow{\alpha \times} \mu$ implies that the spectral distribution of $\mu_{n}$ converges to the spectral distribution of $\mu$ in the large limit as $n \rightarrow \infty$. To simplify notation, throughout the paper, we tag User-1 as the intended user, and will sometimes drop index $k=1$ when referring to the tagged user.

## II. System Model

We consider a single-cell uplink communication system, where multiple users, each equipped with multiple antennas, transmit data symbols to a multi-antenna BS with a Uniform Linear Array (ULA)(see Figure 2). The number of antennas employed at each user is denoted by $N_{t}$ and the number of antennas at the BS is denoted by $N_{r}$. Each user transmits $M$ data frames with sizes $q_{1}, \ldots, q_{M}$, as illustrated in Figure 1. Each frame consists of one pilot (training) time slot for CSIT, with the remaining slots dedicated to data transmission. We adopt a narrowband model, where multiple subcarriers fall within the coherent bandwidth and experience similar channel conditions, eliminating the need for a frequency-domain index. These subcarriers support Zadoff-Chu sequence-based pilots, enabling user separation in the code domain, ensuring pilot orthogonality while avoiding interference. This approach is consistent with prior works [9], [22], and [8]. In what follows, we describe the channel model and the received signal model at pilot and data time slots. The time slot $i$ refers to the symbol time $i T_{s}$, where $T_{s}$ is the symbol period. Without loss of generality, we assume the symbol period $T_{s}=1$.

## A. Channel Model

The channel matrix at time slot $t$ between user $i$ and the BS is denoted by $\mathbf{H}_{i}(t) \in \mathbb{C}^{N_{r} \times N_{t}}$ which is in general a complex non-stationary zero mean random process with Rayleigh distribution.The vectorized version of the channel is obtained by column-wise stacking and is denoted by $\mathbf{h}_{i} \triangleq \operatorname{vec}\left(\mathbf{H}_{i}\right) \in \mathbb{C}^{N \times 1}$ where $N \triangleq N_{t} N_{r}$. The covariance matrix of a typical channel vector hfor user $i$ is shown by $\mathbf{C}_{\mathbf{h}_{i}}(t) \triangleq \mathrm{E}\left[\mathbf{h}_{i}(t) \mathbf{h}_{i}^{H}(t)\right]$. The cross-covariance matrix and the correlation matrix between times $t_{1}$ and $t_{2}$ are given by $\mathbf{C}_{\mathbf{h}_{i}}\left(t_{1}, t_{2}\right) \triangleq \mathrm{E}\left[\mathbf{h}_{i}\left(t_{1}\right) \mathbf{h}_{i}^{H}\left(t_{2}\right)\right]$ and $\mathbf{P}_{\mathbf{h}_{i}}\left(t_{1}, t_{2}\right) \triangleq \mathbf{C}_{\mathbf{h}_{i}}^{-1}\left(t_{1}\right) \mathbf{C}_{\mathbf{h}_{i}}\left(t_{1}, t_{2}\right) \mathbf{C}_{\mathbf{h}_{i}}^{-\frac{1}{2}}\left(t_{2}\right)$, respectively.

## B. Uplink Pilot and Data Model

We consider $M$ frames $m=1, \ldots, M$ in which frame $m$ consists of $q_{m}$ time slots. The first time slot of each frame is devoted to pilot transmission and the rest is employed to
transmit data. Within frame $m$ out of a total of $M$ frames, each communication user transmits $\tau_{p}$ pilot symbols during the first time slot. This is followed by $q_{m}-1$ data time slots, as depicted in Figure 1. We assume that there are at least $K N_{t}$ pilot symbols in the frequency domain, where $K$ is the total number of users and each user has $N_{t}$ transmit antennas. These pilots are mutually orthogonal in the code domain, meaning each user $i$ employs a pilot matrix $\mathbf{S}_{i}$ that satisfies $\mathbf{S}_{i}^{\mathrm{T}} \mathbf{S}_{j}=$ $\tau_{p} \mathbf{I}_{N_{t}}, \quad$ if $i=j$, $\mathbf{0}, \quad$ if $i \neq j$. This ensures that when one user's pilot is processed (e.g., by correlating the received signal with its own pilot matrix), all other users' signals vanish, preventing pilot contamination. Consequently, for the tagged user (User 1), each of its $N_{t}$ antennas occupies its own set of $\tau_{p}$ pilot symbols in the first time slot. Since the pilots of other users remain orthogonal to this set, User 1's channel estimation can be performed independently, free from interference caused by other users' pilots.

Define $\delta_{m} \triangleq\left(\sum_{l=1}^{m} q_{l}\right)+1$. As we assumed $T_{s}=1$, the total transmission duration for all frames is $\delta_{M}-1$ time slots. The time slots of frame $m$ are from $\delta_{m-1}$ to $\delta_{m}-1$. User- $k$ transmits $\tau_{p}$ pilot symbols at power $P_{p, k}$, and data symbols in slot $i$ at power $P_{d, k}(i)$,for $k=1 \ldots K$. Assuming that each user uses a pilot matrix $\mathbf{S}_{i} \in \mathbb{C}^{\tau_{p} \times N_{t}}$, the received pilot signal from the tagged user (User 1) at the BS is given by:

$$
\mathbf{Y}_{1, \mathrm{p}}(t)=\alpha_{1} \sqrt{P_{\mathrm{p}, 1}} \mathbf{H}_{1}(t) \mathbf{S}_{1}^{\mathrm{T}}+\mathbf{N}_{\mathrm{p}}(t) \in \mathbb{C}^{N_{r} \times \tau_{\mathrm{p}}}
$$

where $\mathbf{S}_{1}$ is the pilot matrix of the tagged user, $\alpha_{1}$ represents the large scale fading factor for the tagged user, $P_{\mathrm{p}, 1}$ denotes the pilot power of the tagged user at each pilot time slot, and $\mathbf{N}(t) \in \mathbb{C}^{N_{r} \times \tau_{p}}$ is the additive white Gaussian noise (AWGN) with element-wise variance $\sigma_{\mathrm{p}}^{2}$. It is beneficial to write the equation (1) in a matrix-vector form as follows:
$\mathbf{y}_{1, \mathrm{p}}(t) \triangleq \boldsymbol{\operatorname { v e c }}\left(\mathbf{Y}_{p}(t)\right)=\alpha_{1} \sqrt{P_{\mathrm{p}, 1}} \overline{\mathbf{S}} \mathbf{h}_{1}(t)+\mathbf{n}_{\mathrm{p}}(t) \in \mathbb{C}^{\tau_{\mathrm{p}} N_{r} \times 1}$,
where $\mathbf{y}_{1, \mathrm{p}}(t), \mathbf{n}_{\mathrm{p}}(t) \in \mathbb{C}^{\tau_{\mathrm{p}} N_{r} \times 1}, \overline{\mathbf{S}} \triangleq \mathbf{S}_{1} \otimes \mathbf{I}_{N_{r}} \in \mathbb{C}^{\tau_{\mathrm{p}} N_{r} \times N}$ are such that $\mathbf{S}^{\mathrm{H}} \overline{\mathbf{S}}=\tau_{\mathrm{p}} \mathbf{I}_{N}, \mathbf{h}(t) \triangleq \operatorname{vec}(\mathbf{H}(t))$ and $N \triangleq N_{t} N_{r}$. We also assume that the pilot power corresponding to each pilot time slot is obtained as $P_{\mathrm{p}, 1}=\frac{P_{\mathrm{p}, 1_{\max }}}{M}$, where $P_{\mathrm{p}, 1_{\max }}$ denotes the maximum pilot power of the tagged user.

At data time slot $i$ of frame $m$, the received signal at the BS can be stated as follows:

$$
\mathbf{y}_{\mathrm{d}}(i)=\underbrace{\alpha_{1} \mathbf{H}_{1}(i) \mathbf{x}_{1}(i)}_{\text {tagged user }}+\underbrace{\sum_{k=2}^{K} \alpha_{k} \mathbf{H}_{k}(i) \mathbf{x}_{k}(i)}_{\text {co-scheduled MU-MIMO users }}+\mathbf{n}_{\mathrm{d}}(i) \in \mathbb{C}^{N_{r} \times 1}
$$

where $\alpha_{1}$ is path loss component, $\mathbf{x}_{k}(i) \triangleq \mathbf{w}_{k}^{t} s_{k}(i) \in \mathbb{C}^{N_{t} \times 1}$ is the transmitted signal by the $k$-the user, $s_{k}(i) \in \mathbb{C}^{1 \times 1}$ is the transmitted data symbol of user $k$ with transmit data power $P_{\mathrm{d}, k}=\mathrm{E}\left[\left|s_{k}(i)\right|^{2}\right] . s_{k}(i) \in \mathbb{C}$ is distributed as a zeromean Gaussian random variable. $\mathbf{w}_{k}^{t} \in \mathbb{C}^{N_{t} \times 1}$ is the real-time beamforming vector of $k$-th user corresponding to time slot $i^{1}$. These beamforming vectors will be later optimized to enhance spectral efficiency. Furthermore, $\mathbf{n}_{\mathrm{d}}(i) \sim \mathcal{C N}\left(\mathbf{0}, \sigma_{d}^{2} \mathbf{I}_{N_{r}}\right)$ is

Here, the data power of each data time slot is obtained as $P_{\mathrm{d}, k}=\frac{P_{\mathrm{d}, k_{\max }}}{P_{\mathrm{d}, k-1-M}}$, where $P_{\mathrm{d}, k_{\max }}$ denotes the maximum data power of user $k$. The total power allocated for pilot and data transmission must not exceed the overall power budget, denoted by $P_{\text {tot }}$.

## III. PROPOSED SCHEME

In this section, we provide a road-map of our approach for optimizing beamforming directions, pilot spacing, and power control. First in Section III-A, we establish an explicit link between the velocity of mobile users and the correlation matrix at two different time instants. Then, we provide a linear MMSE (LMMSE) estimate the time-varying channel as a function of frame size in presence of temporal prior information in Section III-B. Next, in Section III-C, we provide an optimal MMSE receiver combiner for AR channels in order to estimate the data message of the tagged user. Next, in Section III-D, based on channel estimate and data estimate, we calculate the instantaneous slot-by-slot SINR of the tagged user over fast fading non-stationary channels. Finally, we present a theorem that provides a deterministic expression for the instantaneous SINR, referred to as the deterministic SINR.

## A. Correlation Matrix in MIMO Channels

In this section, we obtain an explicit relation between the correlation matrix that reflects the temporal correlation information of the channel and the velocity of users. A typical example of the considered vehicular network is depicted in the right image of Figure 2. The correlation matrix of the channel is typically influenced by several factors, including the propagation geometry, user's velocity, and antenna characteristics.

As shown in Figure 2, consider the tagged vehicle moving in the direction $\eta(t)$ at time $t$ with the speed $\nu(t)$. Suppose that the antennas of the BS are aligned in direction $\zeta$ as is shown in Figure 2. The propagation environment between the tagged UE and the BS consists of $L(t)$ number of scatterers. The angle of departure (AoD) and angle of arrival (AoA) of the $i$-th path at time $t$ are denoted by $\theta_{\mathrm{AoD}}^{\mathrm{i}}(t)$ and $\theta_{\mathrm{AoA}}^{\mathrm{i}}(t)$, respectively. Also, the Doppler frequencies of the line of sight (LoS) and non-line of sight (NLoS) paths are obtained by

$$
f_{d}^{\mathrm{ij}}(t)=\frac{\nu(t) \cos \left(\eta(t)-\theta_{\mathrm{AoD}}^{\mathrm{i}}(t)\right)}{2}, f_{d}^{\mathrm{j}}(t)=\frac{\nu(t) \cos \left(\eta(t)-\theta_{\mathrm{AoD}}^{\mathrm{i}}(t)\right)}{4}, i=1, \ldots, L(t)
$$

where $\lambda \triangleq \frac{c}{f_{c}}$ is the wavelength of the source, $c=3 \times 10^{8} \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$ and $f_{c}$ is the carrier frequency. The distance between transmit and receive antennas are respectively denoted by $d_{T}$ and $d_{R}$.

Proposition 1. Assume that the AoDs and AoAs are distributed according to some known distributions. Then, the correlation matrix for the tagged channel, denoted by $\mathbf{h} \triangleq \mathbf{h}_{1}$, can be obtained as

$$
\mathbf{P}_{\mathbf{h}}\left(t_{1}, t_{2}\right)=\mathbf{P}_{\mathbf{h}}^{-\frac{1}{\lambda}}\left(t_{1}\right) \boldsymbol{\Delta}\left(t_{1}, t_{2}\right) \mathbf{P}_{\mathbf{h}}^{-\frac{1}{\lambda}}\left(t_{2}\right) \in \mathbb{C}^{N \times N}
$$

where $\boldsymbol{\Delta}\left(t_{1}, t_{2}\right)$ is obtained in the following.
$\rho\left(t_{1}, t_{2}, p, q, v, w\right) \triangleq\left[\boldsymbol{\Delta}\left(t_{1}, t_{2}\right)\right]_{N_{t}(p-1)+v, N_{t}(q-1)+w} \triangleq$
$\mathbb{E}\left[\mathrm{e}^{j \frac{2 \pi}{\lambda}\left[\left(t_{1} \nu\left(t_{1}\right)+d_{T} v\right) \cos \left(\eta\left(t_{1}\right)-\theta_{\mathrm{AoD}}\left(t_{1}\right)\right)-\left(t_{2} \nu\left(t_{2}\right)+d_{T} w\right) \cos \left(\eta\left(t_{2}\right)-\theta_{\mathrm{AoD}}\left(t_{2}\right)\right)}\right]$
$\mathbb{E}\left[\mathrm{e}^{j \frac{2 \pi d_{R}}{\lambda}\left[p \cos \left(\alpha-\theta_{\mathrm{AoA}}\left(t_{1}\right)\right)-q \cos \left(\alpha-\theta_{\mathrm{AoA}}\left(t_{2}\right)\right)\right]}\right] \triangleq I_{1} I_{2}$
Proof:See Appendix A.
The formulas provided in (6) can be fully calculated by numerical integration. This model aligns with non-isotropic scattering (more detailed can be found in [13], [43], [44]).

Corollary 1. (Special cases: Stationary environments and von Mises distribution for AoA and AoD) In the stationary cases where the statistics of the user and environment do not change with time, then the parameters $\nu(t)=\nu, \eta(t)=\eta, \theta_{\mathrm{AoA}}(t)=$ $\theta_{\mathrm{AoA}}, \theta_{\mathrm{AoD}}(t)=\theta_{\mathrm{AoD}}$ are fixed. Define $\tau \triangleq t_{2}-t_{1}$ and $n_{R} \triangleq$ $q-p, n_{T} \triangleq w-v$. Assume that the AoD follows the von Mises distribution with the probability density functions (PDFs) given by

$$
f\left(\theta_{\mathrm{AoD}}\right)=\frac{\mathrm{e}^{\kappa_{\mathrm{AoD}} \cos \left(\theta_{\mathrm{AoD}}-\theta_{\mathrm{AoD}}^{\mathrm{i}}\right)}}{2 \pi J_{0}\left(j \kappa_{\mathrm{AoD}}\right)}, f\left(\theta_{\mathrm{AoA}}\right)=\frac{\mathrm{e}^{\kappa_{\mathrm{AoA}} \cos \left(\theta_{\mathrm{AoA}}-\theta_{\mathrm{AoA}}^{\mathrm{i}}\right)}}{2 \pi J_{0}\left(j \kappa_{\mathrm{AoA}}\right)}
$$

where $\theta_{\mathrm{AoD}}^{\mathrm{i}}$ is the central AoD and $\kappa_{\mathrm{AoD}}$ is a measure of dispersion from central AoD. Similarly, $\theta_{\mathrm{AoA}}^{\mathrm{o}}$ and $\kappa_{\mathrm{AoA}}$ are defined for the AoA. Given these assumptions and by using (6), the $\left(N_{t}(p-1)+v, N_{t}(q-1)+w\right)$ element of the correlation matrix $\mathbf{P}_{\mathbf{h}}\left(t_{1}, t_{2}\right)$ is obtained as
$\rho\left(t_{1}, t_{2}, p, q, v, w\right)=I_{1} I_{2}, \forall p, q=1, \ldots, N_{r} \quad v, w=1, \ldots, N_{t}$,
where $I_{1}$ and $I_{2}$ are provided in the following:
$I_{1}=\frac{J_{0}\left(j \sqrt{\kappa_{\mathrm{AoD}}^{\mathrm{i}}-\frac{4 \pi^{2}}{\lambda^{2}}\left(\tau \nu+d_{T} n_{T}\right)^{2}-j \frac{4 \pi}{\lambda}\left(\tau \nu+d_{T} n_{T}\right) \kappa_{\mathrm{AoD}} \cos \left(\eta-\theta_{\mathrm{AoD}}^{\mathrm{i}}\right)}\right)}{J_{0}\left(j \kappa_{\mathrm{AoD}}\right)}$

$$
I_{2}=\frac{J_{0}\left(2 \sqrt{\kappa_{\mathrm{AoA}}^{2}-\frac{4 \pi^{2}}{\lambda^{2}} n_{R}^{2} d_{R}^{2}+j \frac{4 \pi}{\lambda} n_{R} d_{R} \kappa_{\mathrm{AoA}} \cos \left(\alpha-\theta_{\mathrm{AoA}}^{z}\right)}\right)}{J_{0}\left(j \kappa_{\mathrm{AoA}}\right)}
$$

Corollary 2. (Special cases: Stationary environment and uniform angles). In the case where the AoD and AoA are distributed uniformly between $[-\pi, \pi]$, we have $\kappa_{\mathrm{AoD}}=\kappa_{\mathrm{AoA}}=$ 0 and the $\left(N_{t}(p-1)+v, N_{t}(q-1)+w\right)$ element of the correlation matrix $\mathbf{P}_{\mathbf{h}}\left(t_{1}, t_{2}\right)$ is obtained as

$$
\rho\left(t_{1}, t_{2}, p, q, v, w\right)=J_{0}\left(\frac{2 \pi}{\lambda} n_{R} d_{R}\right) J_{0}\left(\frac{2 \pi}{\lambda}\left(\tau \nu+d_{T} n_{T}\right)\right)
$$

In the case of having only single transmit antenna, it holds that $d_{T}=0$ and the relation (11) aligns with the well-established Jakes model provided in [43, Eq. 4] and [44].

## B. LMMSE Channel Estimation with Prior Information

We assume that in each data slot $i$ of frame $m$, the BS utilizes the pilot signals of the current and previous frames to estimate the channel of the tagged user in data time slots of the current frame. According to (1), the observed measurements at the pilot time slots corresponding to frames $m-1$ and $m$ are given by:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathbf{Y}_{1, \mathrm{p}}\left(\delta_{m-2}\right)=\alpha_{1} \sqrt{P_{\mathrm{p}, 1}} \mathbf{H}_{1}\left(\delta_{m-2}\right) \mathbf{S}_{1}^{\mathrm{T}}+\mathbf{N}_{p}\left(\delta_{m-2}\right) \\
& \mathbf{Y}_{1, \mathrm{p}}\left(\delta_{m-1}\right)=\alpha_{1} \sqrt{P_{\mathrm{p}, 1}} \mathbf{H}_{1}\left(\delta_{m-1}\right) \mathbf{S}_{1}^{\mathrm{T}}+\mathbf{N}_{p}\left(\delta_{m-1}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

By stacking the above relations in matrix-vector form, we have that

$$
\mathbf{y}_{1, \mathrm{p}} \triangleq\left[\begin{array}{l}
\operatorname{vec}\left(\mathbf{Y}_{1, \mathrm{p}}\left(\delta_{m-2}\right)\right) \\
\operatorname{vec}\left(\mathbf{Y}_{1, \mathrm{p}}\left(\delta_{m-1}\right)\right)
\end{array}\right]=\tilde{\mathbf{S}} \mathbf{h}_{1, \mathrm{p}}+\boldsymbol{\epsilon}_{\mathrm{p}} \in \mathbb{C}^{2 N_{r} \tau_{\mathrm{p}} \times 1}
$$

where $\mathbf{h}_{1, \mathrm{p}}=\left[\begin{array}{l}\mathbf{h}_{1}\left(\delta_{m-2}\right) \\ \mathbf{h}_{1}\left(\delta_{m-1}\right)\end{array}\right] \in \mathbb{C}^{2 N \times 1}, \tilde{\mathbf{S}}=\mathbf{S}_{1} \otimes \mathbf{I}_{2 N_{r}}$ and $\boldsymbol{\epsilon}_{\mathrm{p}} \sim$ $\mathcal{C N}\left(\mathbf{0}, \sigma_{\mathrm{p}, 1}^{2} \mathbf{I}_{2 N_{r} \tau_{\mathrm{p}}}\right)$. Note that as a convention, we assumed that $q_{l}=0 \forall l \leqslant 0$. Having the measurements in pilot time slots provided in (13), one can estimate the channel at data time slot $i$ in frame $m$ as is stated in the following lemma.

Lemma 1. ( [30, Lemma 1 and Corollary 1]) The LMMSE estimate of the channel vector at time slot $i$ of frame $m$ given the measurements $\mathbf{y}_{\mathrm{p}}$ in (13) is obtained as

$$
\widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{1}(i)=\frac{1}{\alpha_{1} \sqrt{P_{\mathrm{p}} \tau_{\mathrm{p}}}} \mathbf{E}(\mathbf{q}, i)\left(\mathbf{M}_{m}(\mathbf{q})+\frac{\sigma_{\mathrm{p}, 1}^{2}}{\alpha_{1}^{2} P_{\mathrm{p}, 1} \tau_{\mathrm{p}}} \mathbf{I}_{2 N}\right)^{-1} \tilde{\mathbf{S}}^{\mathrm{H}} \mathbf{y}_{1, \mathrm{p}}
$$

Moreover, the covariance matrix of the LMMSE channel estimate is provided by:

$$
\mathbf{C}_{\widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{1}}(i)=\mathbf{E}_{m}(\mathbf{q}, i)\left(\mathbf{M}_{m}(\mathbf{q})+\frac{\sigma_{\mathbf{p}, 1}^{2}}{\tau_{\mathrm{p}} \alpha_{1}^{2} P_{\mathrm{p}, 1}} \mathbf{I}_{2 N}\right)^{-1} \mathbf{E}_{m}^{\mathrm{H}}(\mathbf{q}, i)
$$

Here,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathbf{E}_{m}(\mathbf{q}, i) \triangleq\left[\begin{array}{ll}
\mathbf{C}_{\mathbf{h}_{1}}\left(\delta_{m-2}, i\right) & \mathbf{C}_{\mathbf{h}_{1}}\left(\delta_{m-1}, i\right)
\end{array}\right] \\
& \mathbf{M}_{m}(\mathbf{q}) \triangleq\left[\begin{array}{ccc}
\mathbf{C}_{\mathbf{h}_{1}}\left(\delta_{m-2}\right) & \mathbf{C}_{\mathbf{h}_{1}}\left(\delta_{m-2}, \delta_{m-1}\right) \\
\mathbf{C}_{\mathbf{h}_{1}}\left(\delta_{m-1}, \delta_{m-2}\right) & \mathbf{C}_{\mathbf{h}_{1}}\left(\delta_{m-1}\right)
\end{array}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

## D. SINR and SE Calculations

In this subsection, we will calculate the instantaneous SINR based on channel and data estimates provided in Sections III-B and III-C. The following theorem calculates the instantaneous SINR for the tagged user.

Theorem 1. Given the channel estimate $\widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{1}(i)$ of the tagged user, the receiver utilizes the MMSE combiner to estimate the data symbols of the tagged user during time slot $i$. Consequently, the instantaneous SINR of the data symbol for the tagged user at time slot $i$ is derived as follows:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\gamma(\mathbf{q}, i, \widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{1}(i)) & =\alpha_{1}^{2} \widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{1}^{\mathrm{H}}\left(\mathbf{C}_{\mathbf{x}_{1}} \otimes\left(\mathbf{F}(i)-\alpha_{1}^{2} \mathcal{A}_{1}\left(\widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{1} \widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{1}^{\mathrm{H}}\right)\right)^{-1}\right) \widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{1} \\
& \triangleq \alpha_{1}^{2} \widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{1}^{\mathrm{H}}\left(\mathbf{C}_{\mathbf{x}_{1}} \otimes \mathbf{F}_{1}^{-1}(i)\right) \widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{1}
\end{aligned}
$$

where

$$
\mathbf{F}_{1} \triangleq \mathbf{F}_{1}(i) \triangleq \mathbf{F}(i)-\alpha_{1}^{2} \mathcal{A}_{1}\left(\widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{1} \widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{1}^{\mathrm{H}}\right)
$$

Proof: See Appendix B.
The latter result immediately leads to finding the random SE as follows:

$$
\operatorname{SE}\left(\mathbf{q}, i, \widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{1}(i)\right) \triangleq \log \left(1+\gamma\left(\mathbf{q}, i, \widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{1}(i)\right)\right)
$$

which is a random variable. In the following theorem, utilizing concentration inequality findings from the tools of random matrix theory, as provided in [45], we provide a deterministic equivalent formulation for the SE. This expression offers a suitable approximation for the average SE in scenarios where the number of BS antennas is sufficiently large.
Theorem 2. Define $\boldsymbol{\Theta} \triangleq \sum_{k=1}^{K} \alpha_{k}^{2} \mathcal{A}_{k}\left(\mathbf{Q}_{k}\right)$ and $\rho_{\mathrm{d}} \triangleq \sigma_{\mathrm{d}}^{2}$. Assume that $\mathbf{C}_{\widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{\mathrm{k}}}, k=1, \ldots, K$ have uniformly bounded spectral norms with respect to $N$. Then, when $N_{r}$ is sufficiently large $\left(N_{r} \rightarrow\right.$ $\infty$ ), the instantaneous SE provided in (25) is concentrated around a deterministic expression given by:

$$
\mathrm{SE}^{\circ}\left(\mathbf{q}, i, \mathbf{w}^{i}\right) \triangleq \log _{2}(1+\mathrm{E}[\gamma])-\frac{\operatorname{var}(\gamma)}{2 \ln (2)(1+\mathrm{E}[\gamma])^{2}}
$$

where

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathrm{E}[\gamma] \xrightarrow{\alpha_{A}} P_{\mathrm{d}, 1} \alpha_{1}^{2}\left\langle\mathbf{C}_{\widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{\mathrm{k}}(i)}, \mathbf{w}^{i} \mathbf{w}^{i^{H}} \otimes \mathbf{T}\left(\rho_{\mathrm{d}}\right)\right\rangle \\
& \operatorname{var}(\gamma) \xrightarrow{\alpha_{A}} 2 P_{\mathrm{d}, 1} \alpha_{1}^{2}\left\langle\mathbf{C}_{\mathbf{h}_{1}}, \mathbf{w}^{i} \mathbf{w}^{i^{H}} \otimes \mathbf{T}^{\prime}\left(\rho_{\mathrm{d}}\right)\right\rangle
\end{aligned}
$$

and

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathbf{T}\left(\rho_{\mathrm{d}}\right) \triangleq\left(\sum_{k=2}^{K} \frac{\alpha_{k}^{2} \mathcal{A}_{k}\left(\mathbf{C}_{\widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{\mathrm{k}}}\right)}{1+\omega_{k}}+\boldsymbol{\Theta}+\rho_{\mathrm{d}} \mathbf{I}_{N_{r}}\right)^{-1} \\
& \mathbf{T}^{\prime}\left(\rho_{\mathrm{d}}\right)=\mathbf{T}\left(\rho_{\mathrm{d}}\right)\left(\alpha_{1}^{2} \mathcal{A}_{1}\left(\mathbf{C}_{\widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{1}}\right)+\sum_{k=2}^{K} \frac{\omega_{k}^{\prime} \alpha_{k}^{2} \mathcal{A}_{k}\left(\mathbf{C}_{\widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{\mathrm{k}}}\right)}{\left(1+\omega_{k}\right)^{2}}\right) \mathbf{T}\left(\rho_{\mathrm{d}}\right) \\
& \boldsymbol{\omega}^{\prime} \triangleq\left[\omega_{2}^{\prime}, \ldots, \omega_{K}^{\prime}\right]^{T}=\left(\mathbf{I}_{K-1}-\mathbf{J}\right)^{-1} \mathbf{v}^{\prime} \\
& J_{k, l} \triangleq \frac{\operatorname{tr}\left(\alpha_{k}^{2} \alpha_{l}^{2} \mathcal{A}_{k}\left(\mathbf{C}_{\widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{\mathrm{k}}}\right) \mathbf{T}\left(\rho_{\mathrm{d}}\right) \mathcal{A}_{l}\left(\mathbf{C}_{\widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{l}}\right) \mathbf{T}\left(\rho_{\mathrm{d}}\right)\right)}{\left(1+\omega_{l}\right)^{2}}, k, l=2, \ldots, K \\
& v_{k}^{\prime}=\operatorname{tr}\left(\alpha_{k}^{2} \alpha_{1}^{2} \mathcal{A}_{k}\left(\mathbf{C}_{\widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{\mathrm{k}}}\right) \mathbf{T}\left(\rho_{\mathrm{d}}\right) \mathcal{A}_{1}\left(\mathbf{C}_{\widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{1}}\right) \mathbf{T}\left(\rho_{\mathrm{d}}\right)\right), k=2, \ldots, K
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\omega_{2}, \ldots, \omega_{K}$ are the solution of the following system of
equations for $k=2, \ldots, K$ :

$$
\omega_{k}=\left\langle\alpha_{k}^{2} \mathbf{C}_{\widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{\mathrm{k}}(i)}, \mathbf{C}_{\mathbf{x}_{k}} \otimes \mathbf{T}\left(\rho_{\mathrm{d}}\right)\right\rangle
$$

Proof:See Appendix C.
Remark 1. (Relevance of Theorem 2 to prior arts) To compare with prior works, we assume for simplicity that $N_{t}=1, \alpha_{i}=$ $1, i=1, \ldots, K$ and thus there is no beamforming vectors. The output of the MMSE linear detector for the tagged user (User 1) is given by:

$$
r_{1}=\mathbf{g}_{1}^{H} \mathbf{h}_{1} s_{1}+\sum_{l \neq 1} \mathbf{g}_{1}^{H} \mathbf{h}_{l} s_{l}+\mathbf{g}_{1}^{H} \mathbf{n}_{d}
$$

Let $\mathbf{h}_{i}=\widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{i}+\widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{i}$. We rewrite (31) as follows:

$$
r_{1}=\mathbf{g}_{1}^{H} \widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{1} s_{1}+\sum_{l \neq 1} \mathbf{g}_{1}^{H} \widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{l} s_{l}+\sum_{l=1}^{K} \mathbf{g}_{1}^{H} \widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{l} s_{l}+\mathbf{g}_{1}^{H} \mathbf{n}_{d}
$$

Given the channel estimates are known and the channel estimate errors are unknown to the receiver, an achievable rate is obtained in [7] which is a lower-bound for the ergodic capacity (see e.g. [39, Eq: 2.42]) and is given as follows:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& C \geqslant \mathrm{E}\left[\log _{2}\left(1+\frac{P_{\mathrm{d}_{1}}\left[\mathbf{g}_{1}^{H} \widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{1}\right]^{2}}{\sum_{l \neq 1}\left[\mathbf{g}_{1}^{H} \widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{l}\right]^{2} P_{\mathrm{d}_{1}}+\sum_{l=1}^{K} \mathrm{E}\left[\left[\mathbf{g}_{1}^{H} \widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{l}\right]^{2}\right] P_{\mathrm{d}_{l}}+\sigma_{\mathrm{d}}^{2}\left[\mathbf{g}_{1}\right]_{2}^{2}}\right)\right] \\
& \triangleq \mathrm{E}\left[\log _{2}(1+\mathrm{SINR})\right] \triangleq \mathrm{E}[\mathrm{SE}]
\end{aligned}
$$

where SINR and SE are respectively called the effective instantaneous SINR and SE.

The authors in [39] proposed an approach to find a lowerbound for the above expected spectral efficiency i.e. E[SE] known as Use and Then Forget (UTF) by rewriting (31) as follows (see e.g. [46, Eq. 9], [47, Eq. 40], [39, Sec. 3.2.2]):

$$
r_{1}=\underbrace{\mathrm{E}\left[\mathbf{g}_{1}^{H} \mathbf{h}_{1}\right] s_{1}}_{\text {Desired signal }}+\underbrace{\sum_{l=1}^{K} \mathbf{g}_{l}^{H} \mathbf{h}_{l} s_{l}-\mathrm{E}\left[\mathbf{g}_{1}^{H} \mathbf{h}_{1}\right] s_{1}}_{\text {Ionoforence }}+\underbrace{\mathbf{g}_{1}^{H} n_{d}}_{\text {note }} .
$$

This leads to the following lower-bound on the capacity:
UTF lower bound $=\log _{2}\left(1+\underbrace{\left.P_{\mathrm{d}_{1}}\left[\mathrm{E}\left[\mathbf{g}_{1}^{H} \mathbf{h}_{1}\right]\right]^{2}\right]}_{\sum_{l=1}^{K} P_{\mathrm{d}_{l}} \mathrm{E}\left[\left[\mathbf{g}_{1}^{H} \widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{l}\right]^{2}\right]-P_{\mathrm{d}_{l}}\left[\mathrm{E}\left[\mathbf{g}_{1}^{H} \widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{l}\right]\right]^{2}+\sigma_{d}^{2} \mathrm{E}\left[\left[\mathbf{g}_{1}\right]_{2}^{2}\right]}\right) .$
The UTF lower-bound in initially provided in [41] based on the approach of [7] has been also exploited in several recent works such as [39], [47], [48] and serves as a simple lower-bound to approximate the expected spectral efficiency. This strategy is explained in details in [48, Lemma 2] or [46, Eq. 9] for MRC combiner. The numerator and denominator of UTF lowerbound is calculated based on Monte-Carlo simulations and there is not closed-form expression that predicts the behavior of UTF lower-bound in the asymptotic case for MMSE receiver. Hoydis et.al in [8] found an approximation for the expected SINR E[SINR] by founding deterministic equivalent expressions for the numerator and denominator of the instantaneous SINR in the large limit. This means implicitly passing the expectation into both numerator and denominator. Then, they use Jensen's upper-bound to approximate the expected spectral efficiency as $\log _{2}(1+\mathrm{E}[\mathrm{SINR}])$. It is worth mentioning that the latter operation does not necessarily lead to a lowerbound or upper-bound for the expected SINR. Sometimes, it overestimates $\mathrm{E}[\mathrm{SE}]$ and sometimes it underestimates $\mathrm{E}[\mathrm{SE}]$.

This bound also serves as an upper-bound for UTF lowerbound in (35) and sometimes predicts the UTF bound very well. Additionally, their approach which is based on [34], [37] requires the number of users be much less than the number of antenna i.e, $K \ll N$. Moreover, Ngo et.al in [40, Eq. 25] has found a lower-bound for $\mathbb{E}[\mathrm{SE}]$ in case of MMSE receiver as follows:

$$
\mathbb{E}[\mathrm{SE}] \geqslant \log _{2}\left(1+\frac{1}{\mathbb{E}\left[\frac{1}{\gamma_{\text {lower }}}\right]}\right)
$$

where $\gamma_{\text {lower }} \triangleq \frac{1}{\left[\left(\mathbf{I}_{K}+\frac{1}{\alpha^{2}} \mathbf{H}_{\text {tot }}^{2} \mathbf{H}_{\text {tot }}\right)^{-1}\right]_{1,1}}-1$ and $\mathbf{H}_{\text {tot }} \triangleq$ $\left[\mathbf{h}_{1}, \mathbf{h}_{2}, \ldots, \mathbf{h}_{K}\right] \in \mathbb{C}^{N \times K}$. Couillet et.al in [42] proposed another bound based on Jensen's upper-bound given by

$$
\mathbb{E}[\mathrm{SE}] \leqslant \log _{2}(1+\mathbb{E}[\text { SINR }])
$$

and proved that when both transmit and receive number of antennas goes to infinity, this bound serves a good approximation for the expected spectral efficiency but overestimates the spectral efficiency in medium and small number of antennas.

The deterministic equivalent SE provided in (26) depends on the beamforming vectors $\mathbf{w}_{1}^{i}, \ldots, \mathbf{w}_{K}^{i}$ of size $N_{t} \times 1$. We further find the optimal value of the beamforming vector of the tagged user at time slot $i$ in the following proposition.
Proposition 3. Partition the matrix $\mathbf{C}_{\tilde{\mathbf{h}}_{1}}$ as below:

$$
\mathbf{C}_{\tilde{\mathbf{h}}_{i}}=\left[\begin{array}{ccc}
\mathbf{C}_{\tilde{\mathbf{h}}_{1}}^{1,1} & \ldots & \mathbf{C}_{\tilde{\mathbf{h}}_{i}}^{i, N_{c}} \\
\vdots & \ddots & \vdots \\
\mathbf{C}_{\tilde{\mathbf{h}}_{i}}^{N_{c}, 1} & \ldots & \mathbf{C}_{\tilde{\mathbf{h}}_{i}}^{N_{c} N_{c}}
\end{array}\right]
$$

Define the linear operator $\mathcal{G}(\cdot): \mathbb{C}^{N \times N} \rightarrow \mathbb{C}^{N_{t} \times N_{t}}$ as

$$
\mathcal{G}\left(\mathbf{C}_{\tilde{\mathbf{h}}_{1}}\right)=\sum_{i, l=1}^{N_{c}} T(i, l) \mathbf{C}_{\tilde{\mathbf{h}}_{1}}^{i, l}
$$

where $\mathbf{T} \triangleq \mathbf{T}\left(\rho_{\mathrm{d}}\right)$ is given in (28). Then, the optimal real-time beamformer $\mathbf{w}_{1}{ }^{i \star}$ that maximizes the deterministic equivalent $S E$ provided in (26) is the eigenvector of $\mathbf{T}\left(\rho_{\mathrm{d}}\right)$ that corresponds to the maximum eigenvalue of $\mathbf{T}\left(\rho_{\mathrm{d}}\right)$.

Proof:See Appendix D.
In what follows, we provide an optimization problem that finds the optimal values of $M, q_{m}, P_{\mathrm{p}, 1_{\max }}$ and $P_{\mathrm{d}, 1_{\max }}$. The objective function that we use is obtained by replacing the optimal $\mathbf{w}_{1}{ }^{i \star}$ into the formula (26) and taking average over all time slots, which is named Detetministic Averaged Spectral Efficiency (DASE), and is given by

$$
\mathrm{DASE}=\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{d} \mathrm{SE}^{\circ}\left(\mathbf{q}, l, \mathbf{w}_{1}^{i \star}\right)}{\delta_{M}-1}
$$

By having this objective function, the proposed optimization problem is as follows:

$$
\max _{\mathbf{q}, M, P_{\mathrm{p}_{\max }}, P_{\mathrm{d} \max }} \frac{\sum_{i=1}^{d} M^{-1} \mathrm{SE}^{\circ}\left(\mathbf{q}, l, \mathbf{w}_{1}^{i \star}\right)}{\delta_{M}-1}
$$

s.t. $P_{\mathrm{p}_{\max }}+P_{\mathrm{d} \max } \leqslant P_{\text {tot }}$,
where $P_{\mathrm{d} \max }=P_{\mathrm{d}, 1_{\max }}$ and $P_{\mathrm{p}_{\max }}=P_{\mathrm{p}, 1_{\max }}$ denote the maximum data and pilot power of the tagged user, respectively.
Remark 2. (Critical factors in the proposed optimization problem (41).) The numerical experiments presented in Section

IV indicate that neither the Doppler frequency of interfering users nor the interference path significantly impact the determination of the optimal frame design ( $\mathbf{q}^{\star}$ and $M^{\star}$ ). Furthermore, as the number of transmit antennas increases, the variations in spectral efficiency (SE) of the tagged user due to different interference path losses and Doppler frequencies become negligible. This observation highlights the transmittercentric nature of our approach, allowing all optimization tasks to be efficiently executed at the transmitter side rather than the receiver (BS) side. More specifically, users are assumed to predict their own velocities for future time instances, enabling them to determine the optimal frame size and number of frames using our proposed strategy without requiring knowledge of the time-varying covariance matrices. However, obtaining the optimal pilot and data power allocation necessitates predicting these covariance matrices over time. This can be achieved through advanced Kalman filtering techniques [49] or machine learning models [50].

The optimization problem (41) is a non-polynomial time (NP)-hard mixed-integer nonlinear problem. In this section, we present a heuristic algorithm named OptResource for determining the optimal values of frame size, number of frames, and pilot and data powers. The pseudocode for this algorithm is outlined in Algorithm 1. For each number of frames and frame size, an estimation of the beamforming vectors is obtained based on an estimate of the pilot and data powers, using Proposition 3 in Line 10. Subsequently, a projected gradient ascent is employed to identify the optimal values of pilot and data powers (Lines 12 to 19). The projected gradient ascent involves two steps: the update step and projection. In the update step (Line 15), a regular gradient ascent is performed. However, the resulting power variables after this step may fall outside the feasible region (where the sum of pilot and power must be less than the total power budget). To address this, the updated power variables are projected in Line 17 to the nearest point within the feasible region. After determining the optimal pilot and data powers, Line 10 is again used to update the beamforming, and an alternative optimization (AO) approach is applied to jointly find the optimum beamforming and powers. The algorithm iterates through all possible values of $M$ and $q_{m}$ to identify the combination leading to the maximum spectral efficiency. The final outputs of OptResource are $\mathbf{q}^{\star}, M^{\star}, P_{\mathrm{p}, 1_{\max }}^{\star}, P_{\mathrm{d}, 1_{\max }}^{\star}, \mathbf{W}_{\mathrm{B}}^{\star}=\left[\mathbf{w}_{1}^{1^{\star}}, \ldots, \mathbf{w}_{1}^{\delta_{M^{\star}}-1^{\star}}\right]$. The computational complexity of the projected gradient ascent depends on the dimensionality of the optimization vector, which, in our case, is two. Additionally, computing the DASE (Equation 40) at each time slot requires implementing a fixedpoint algorithm with a computational complexity of $\mathcal{O}(K-1)$. Furthermore, obtaining the covariance matrices $\mathbf{C}_{\tilde{\mathbf{h}}_{l}}$ for each $l=1, \ldots, K$ involves the solution of Equation 15, which requires $\mathcal{O}\left(N^{3}\right)$ computations. In summary, the overall computational complexity is $\mathcal{O}\left(q_{\max }(K-1) N^{3}\right)$.

Remark 3. (Convergence analysis) The convergence of Algorithm 1 is directly linked to the convergence properties of computing the deterministic spectral efficiency in Equation (26). A detailed convergence analysis is presented in the following proposition, which is adapted from [51, Appendix

I.B] and Vitali's convergence theorem [52]:

Proposition 4. Let $\omega_{l}^{(p)}, l=2, \ldots, K$ be the $p$-th iteration of the following fixed-point equation

$$
\omega_{k}^{(p+1)}=\left\langle\mathbf{C}_{\mathbf{h}_{k}}(i),\left(\sum_{l=2}^{K} \frac{\mathbf{C}_{\mathbf{h}_{l}}(i)}{1+\omega_{l}^{(p)}}+\boldsymbol{\Theta}+\rho_{\mathrm{d}} \mathbf{I}_{N_{r}}\right)^{-1}\right\rangle
$$

with the initial point $\omega_{l}^{(0)}=\frac{1}{\rho_{\mathrm{d}}}$. Then, it holds that

$$
\left|\omega_{l}^{(p+1)}-\omega_{l}^{(p)}\right| \leqslant \frac{1}{\rho_{\mathrm{d}}^{2}} \sup _{2 \leqslant l \leqslant K}\left|\omega_{l}^{(p)}-\omega_{l}^{(p-1)}\right|
$$

and for $l=2, \ldots, K$ the iteration converges to $\lim _{p \rightarrow \infty} \omega_{l}^{(p)}=$ $\omega_{l}$, defined in (30).

## IV. NUMERICAL RESULTS

In this section, we present numerical experiments to evaluate the performance of the proposed method and compare its effectiveness with several alternative bounds and methods. The analysis focuses on the tightness of these bounds with respect to the expected SE.

Experimental Setup: The first experiment investigates the capacity bound provided in Theorem 2, comparing it with the actual expected spectral efficiency $\mathbb{E}[\mathrm{SE}]$ and four other methods:

1) Actual Expected SE $(\mathbb{E}[\mathrm{SE}])$ : Calculated as the average of 10000 Monte Carlo realizations of the instantaneous SE from (25).
2) UTF Bound (Monte Carlo): Derived using (35), with both the numerator and denominator approximated using 10000 Monte Carlo simulations.
3) Hoydis Bound (Deterministic Equivalent): Computed using deterministic equivalent expressions for the numerator and denominator, as outlined in [8].
4) Ngo Lower-Bound: From [40, Eq. 25], calculated using (36), where $\mathbb{E}\left[\frac{1}{\gamma_{\text {lower }}}\right]$ is approximated via 10000 Monte Carlo iterations.
5) Jensen's upper-bound: The Jensen's upper-bound for the expected SE given in (37) is calculated using Monte

2) Millimeter-Wave (mm-wave) Channels: These channels are characterized by limited scattering, with AoA concentrated around a central angle or certain clusters of angles, leading to low-rank channel covariance matrices.
The channels corresponding to the users $(i=1, \ldots, K)$ are given by $\mathbf{C}_{\mathbf{I}_{i}}=\sigma_{i}^{2} \mathbf{B}_{i} \mathbf{B}_{i}^{H}$ where $\mathbf{B}_{i} \in \mathbb{C}^{N \times r}$ is a matrix whose columns form steering vectors and $r$ is the rank of the covariance matrix. The variance of the interfering channels is assumed to be equal to $\sigma_{\text {inter }}^{2}$. The signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) is defined as $\mathrm{SNR}=10 \log _{10}\left(\frac{P_{\mathrm{d}, i}}{\sigma_{d}^{2}}\right)-\mathrm{PL}_{1}$ where $\mathrm{PL}_{1}=$ $20 \log \left(\alpha_{1}\right)$ is the path loss of the channel corresponding to the tagged user. In the experiments shown in Figure 3, all path
losses are set to $\alpha_{i}=1, i=1, \ldots, K$ and the data powers are $P_{\mathrm{d}, i}=1$.

Figures 3b, 3e, 3g, 3h show results for Rayleigh fading channels with rich scattering environments. In these cases:

- For small and moderate numbers of antennas ( $N$ ), the UTF bound from (35) provides a loose lower-bound for $\mathrm{E}[\mathrm{SE}]$ and the lower-bound from (36) is similarly nontight.
- As we discussed earlier, the Hoydis bound might be an upper-bound for $\mathrm{E}[\mathrm{SE}]$ which overestimates the actual expected SE.
- As $N$ increases, the UTF and Hoydis bounds become tighter and approaches the actual expected SE.
- Our proposed bound (highlighted in red) consistently offers a tight estimate of $\mathrm{E}[\mathrm{SE}]$, even for non-asymptotic values of $N$.
- If there are spatial correlations in the transmit antennas, the UTF bound and Jensen's bound fail to reflect the expected spectral efficiency as can be seen from Figures 3g, 3h.
Figures 3a, 3c, 3d, and 3f illustrate results for mm-wave channels with limited scattering, where the AoAs are nonuniformly distributed around a central angle such as the von Misses distribution. These experiments reveal:
- As it turns out from Figures 3a, 3c, 3d, 3f, the UTF lowerbound (35) is not tight. The gap between the UTF bound and $\mathrm{E}[\mathrm{SE}]$ can be substantial, sometimes exceeding 5 bps/Hz, as seen in Figure 3a.
- The Hoydis theoretical bound may act as either an upper or lower bound depending on the specific scenario, e.g., it serves as a upper-bound in Figures 3c and 3e, but as a lower-bound in Figures 3a, 3a, 3d and 3f. However, it is consistently non-tight, even for large $N$. In addition, the deterministic equivalent expressions provided in [8], derived from random matrix theory, fail to accurately reflect the behavior of the expected spectral efficiency. This failure arises from the inaccuracies in deterministic approximations of the quadratic terms in the numerator and denominator and the fact that passing the expectation operator to both numerator and denominator does not provide necessarily a lower or upper-bound.
- The Ngo lower-bound is loose in all scenarios, offering little practical value.
- Jensen's bound is relatively closer to the actual $\mathrm{E}[\mathrm{SE}]$, but its tightness does not improve asymptotically as $N$ increases.
In all cases, the proposed bound accurately predicts $\mathrm{E}[\mathrm{SE}]$, demonstrating exceptional tightness even for small numbers of antennas. This highlights the robustness and reliability of our approach across both Sub-6GHz and mm-wave channel scenarios.

In the second round of experiments, we will evaluate our approach in pilot spacing and power control, using a Kronecker model for the correlation matrix, where $\mathbf{h}$ represents a typical channel, including the individual channel $\mathbf{h}_{i}$ of each user. The correlation matrix is given by $\mathbf{P}_{\mathbf{h}}\left(t_{1}, t_{2}\right)=\mathbf{P}_{\mathbf{h}, \mathrm{T}}\left(t_{1}, t_{2}\right) \otimes$ $\mathbf{P}_{\mathbf{h}, \mathrm{R}}\left(t_{1}, t_{2}\right)$ where $\mathbf{P}_{\mathbf{h}, \mathrm{T}}\left(t_{1}, t_{2}\right) \in \mathbb{C}^{N_{t} \times N_{t}}$ and $\mathbf{P}_{\mathbf{h}, \mathrm{R}}\left(t_{1}, t_{2}\right) \in$ $\mathbb{C}^{N_{t} \times N_{t}}$ are the correlation matrices of the transmit and receive

antennas, respectively. In the stationary case, we assume in the experiments that $\mathbf{P}_{\mathbf{B}, \mathrm{T}}=\rho_{1} \mathbf{1}_{N_{t}} \mathbf{1}_{N_{t}}^{H}+\left(1-\rho_{1}\right) \mathbf{I}_{N_{t}}$ and $\mathbf{P}_{\mathrm{B}}=\rho_{2} \mathbf{1}_{N_{c}} \mathbf{1}_{N_{c}}^{H}+\left(1-\rho_{2}\right) \mathbf{I}_{N_{c}}$ with $\rho_{1}=0.9, \rho_{2}=0$ which imply that the transmit antennas are close to each other and they are to a great extent correlated and the receive antennas are uncorrelated. The first four experiments are related to the stationary settings, while the rest examine the performance of our method in non-stationary scenarios. However, using multiple antennas leads to higher SE compared to singleantenna case. In the second experiment, shown in the 7th-12th rows of Table I, we examine a scenario where the user is rapidly moving with a high speed in the two cases of $N_{t}=5$ and $N_{t}=1$. This suggests that in multi-antenna transmitter with optimized beamforming, one can allocate the whole power to data time slots while in single-antenna, the power is distributed in two frames, which requires more pilot time slots to achieve the highest possible SE.

While the approach in [29, Eq. 30] predicts a higher SE, it is important to note that the actual SE is lower. This finding suggests that in high-speed scenarios, concentrating the power budget in the initial time slots is advantageous due to the rapidly varying nature of the channel.

From Figure 4c, we observe that utilizing multiple transmit antennas with optimal real-time beamforming can increase the DASE. The level of improvement is also affected by frame size, Doppler and path loss of the tagged user. In Figure 4d, we analyze the impact of $r_{p}=r_{p_{1}}$ on our frame design. It is evident that the power distribution between pilot and data, as represented by $r_{p}=r_{p_{1}}$, influences the optimal frame size. Additionally, employing multiple transmit antennas contributes to an increased SE. Examining Figure 4d, we find that the power ratio between pilot and data time slots plays a crucial role in determining the optimal frame size. Specifically, a higher pilot power results in an augmentation of data time slots. This effect is more pronounced in scenarios with multiple transmit antennas compared to those with a single transmit antenna.

Figure 5a shows that while the interference path loss affects SE, it does not impact the optimal frame design. Furthermore, our observations from Figure 5a suggest that when employing multiple antennas at the transmitter side, the change in SE caused by the interference path loss is considerably smaller than in the single-antenna case. The used parameters in this figure are as follows: $f_{d 1}=f_{d 2}=100, f_{c}=1000, \mathrm{PL}_{1}=$ $1, q_{\max }=6, M_{\max }=1, P_{\mathrm{p}, 1_{\max }}=P_{\mathrm{d}, 1_{\max }}=P_{\mathrm{p}, 2_{\max }}=$ $P_{d, 2_{\max }}=1, N_{r}=10, \tau_{p}=5, \sigma_{p, 1}^{2}=\sigma_{d, 1}^{2}=7.94 \times$ $10^{-5}, \sigma_{p, 2}^{2}=10^{-4}$.

Figure 5b examines the effect of interference Doppler frequency on the optimal frame design and SE. We observe from this figure that while different interference Doppler frequencies lead to different DASE levels, the optimal frame size is fixed

and not sensitive to changing interference Doppler frequency. We also see that the level of change in the resulting DASE is more enhanced in single antenna rather than multi-antenna case. The used parameters in this figure are: $f_{d 1}=100, f_{c}=$ $1000, \mathrm{PL}_{1}=1, \mathrm{PL}_{2}=0, q_{\max }=6, M_{\max }=1, P_{\mathrm{p}, 1_{\max }}=$ $P_{\mathrm{d}, 1_{\max }}=P_{\mathrm{p}, 2_{\max }}=P_{\mathrm{d}, 2_{\max }}=1, N_{r}=10, \tau_{p}=5, \rho_{1}=$ $0.9, \rho_{2}=0, \sigma_{p, 1}^{2}=\sigma_{d, 1}^{2}=7.94 \times 10^{-5}, \sigma_{p, 2}^{2}=10^{-4}$.

In Figure 5c, we observe that changing the pilot and data powers of the interference components can change the DASE while it does not change the optimal frame size. As depicted in Figures 5a, 5b, 5c, a significant observation emerges: as the number of transmit antennas increases, the disparity in multiantenna DASE among different interference factors diminishes. This outcome underscores that, with our proposed method and in scenarios where $N_{t}$ is large, the tagged user can experience approximately uniform SE across various interference path loss and Doppler. The used parameters in this figure are $f_{d 1}=100, f_{c}=1000, \mathrm{PL}_{1}=1, \mathrm{PL}_{2}=0, q_{\max }=6, M_{\max }=$ $1, P_{\mathrm{p}, 1_{\max }}=P_{\mathrm{d}, 1_{\max }}=1, N_{r}=10, \tau_{p}=5, \sigma_{p, 1}^{2}=\sigma_{d, 1}^{2}=$ $7.94 \times 10^{-5}, \sigma_{p, 2}^{2}=10^{-4}$.

## V. CONCLUSIONS

This work delved into the uplink communications of MIMO multi-user systems featuring multiple transmit and receive antennas, operating over fast-fading non-stationary wireless channels that undergo aging between consecutive pilot signals. A dedicated beamforming framework was developed to address spatial correlations among transmit antennas, complemented by a channel estimation process that capitalizes on the temporal correlations of the channel. Subsequently, a deterministic expression was introduced to approximate the average spectral efficiency in scenarios involving multi-frame data transmission. To enhance the performance further, an optimization framework was proposed to determine the optimal values for beamforming vectors, the number of frames, frame sizes, and power control, while satisfying some power constraints. Notably, our optimization approach exclusively leverages the knowledge of the temporal dynamics of the channel, eliminating the need for measurements or channel estimates. More importantly, optimal frame design and pilot spacing were demonstrated to be unaffected by the velocity of interference users and interference path loss. Furthermore, we showed that the impact of interference path loss and velocity diminishes as the number of transmit antennas increases. Simulation results robustly validated the effectiveness of our methodology, underscoring its profound influence on optimizing beamforming, pilot and
data powers, frame sizes, and the number of frames across various practical scenarios.

& \gamma\left(\mathbf{q}, i, \widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{1}(i)\right)=\frac{\alpha_{1}^{2} P_{\mathrm{d}, 1}\left\langle\mathbf{F}^{-1} \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{1} \mathbf{w}_{1} \mathbf{w}_{1}^{\mathrm{H}} \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{1}^{\mathrm{H}} \mathbf{F}^{-1}, \alpha^{2} \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{1} \mathbf{C}_{\mathbf{x}_{1}} \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{1}^{\mathrm{H}}\right\rangle}{\alpha_{1}^{2} P_{1}\left\langle\mathbf{F}^{-1} \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{1} \mathbf{w}_{1} \mathbf{w}_{1}^{\mathrm{H}} \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{1}^{\mathrm{H}} \mathbf{F}^{-1}, \mathbf{F}-\alpha_{1}^{2} \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{1} \mathbf{w}_{1} \mathbf{w}_{1}^{\mathrm{H}} \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{1}^{\mathrm{H}}\right\rangle}= \\
& \frac{\alpha_{1}^{2} P_{\mathrm{d}, 1}\left\langle\mathbf{F}^{-1} \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{1} \mathbf{w}_{1} \mathbf{w}_{1}^{\mathrm{H}} \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{1}^{\mathrm{H}} \mathbf{F}^{-1}, \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{1} \mathbf{C}_{\mathbf{x}_{1}} \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{1}^{\mathrm{H}}\right\rangle}{\left\langle\mathbf{F}^{-1} \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{1} \mathbf{w}_{1} \mathbf{w}_{1}^{\mathrm{H}} \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{1}^{\mathrm{H}} \mathbf{F}^{-1}, F\right\rangle-\alpha_{1}^{2}\left\langle\mathbf{F}^{-1} \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{1} \mathbf{w}_{1} \mathbf{w}_{1}^{\mathrm{H}} \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{1}^{\mathrm{H}} \mathbf{F}^{-1}, \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{1} \mathbf{C}_{\mathbf{x}_{1}} \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{1}^{\mathrm{H}}\right\rangle}
\end{aligned}
$$

When a single symbol is transmitted through multiple antennas at the user side, the covariance matrix satisfy $\mathbf{C}_{\mathbf{x}_{1}}=$ $P_{\mathrm{d}, 1} \mathbf{w}_{1} \mathbf{w}_{1}^{\mathrm{H}}$ where $\left\|\mathbf{w}_{1}\right\|_{2}=1$. By using the rotational invariance property of the Frobenius inner product in the numerator of (58), we can rewrite the numerator of (58) as follows
$\alpha_{1}^{2} P_{\mathrm{d}, 1} \operatorname{tr}\left(\mathbf{F}^{-1} \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{1} \mathbf{w}_{1} \mathbf{w}_{1}^{\mathrm{H}} \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{1}^{\mathrm{H}} \mathbf{F}^{-1} \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{1} \mathbf{w}_{1} \mathbf{w}_{1}^{\mathrm{H}} \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{1}^{\mathrm{H}}\right)=\alpha_{1}^{2} P_{\mathrm{d}, 1}\left(\mathbf{w}_{1}^{\mathrm{H}} \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{1}^{\mathrm{H}} \mathbf{F}^{-1} \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{1} \mathbf{w}_{1}\right)^{2}$.
Also, the first term in the denominator of (58) is simplified as

$$
\operatorname{tr}\left(\mathbf{F}^{-1} \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{1} \mathbf{w}_{1} \mathbf{w}_{1}^{\mathrm{H}} \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{1}^{\mathrm{H}} \mathbf{F}^{-1} \mathbf{F}\right)=\mathbf{w}_{1}^{\mathrm{H}} \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{1}^{\mathrm{H}} \mathbf{F}^{-1} \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{1} \mathbf{w}_{1}
$$

By having (59) and (60), the SINR expression in (58) simplifies to

$$
\gamma\left(\mathbf{q}, i, \widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{1}(i)\right)=\frac{\alpha_{1}^{2} P_{\mathrm{d}, 1} \mathbf{w}_{1}^{\mathrm{H}} \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{1}^{\mathrm{H}} \mathbf{F}^{-1} \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{1} \mathbf{w}_{1}}{1-\alpha_{1}^{2} P_{\mathrm{d}, 1} \mathbf{w}_{1}^{\mathrm{H}} \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{1}^{\mathrm{H}} \mathbf{F}^{-1} \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{1} \mathbf{w}_{1}}
$$

Now, we can use the following lemma whose proof is provided in Appendix G.
Lemma 3. Let $\mathbf{A} \in \mathbb{C}^{N_{r} \times N_{r}}$ be an invertible matrix and $\beta$ is a scalar. For any $\mathbf{z} \in \mathbb{C}^{N_{r} \times 1}$, it holds that

$$
\frac{\mathbf{z}^{\mathrm{H}} \mathbf{A} \mathbf{z}}{\beta-\mathbf{z}^{\mathrm{H}} \mathbf{A} \mathbf{z}}=\mathbf{z}^{\mathrm{H}}\left(\beta \mathbf{A}^{-1}-\mathbf{z} \mathbf{z}^{\mathrm{H}}\right)^{-1} \mathbf{z}
$$

By replacing $\mathbf{z}=\widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{1} \mathbf{w}_{1}$ and $\mathbf{A}=\mathbf{F}^{-1}$ in Lemma 3 and using the definition of $\mathbf{F}_{1}$ in Theorem 1 and Proposition 5, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \gamma\left(\mathbf{q}, i, \widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{1}(i)\right)=\alpha_{1}^{2} P_{\mathrm{d}, 1} \mathbf{w}_{1}^{\mathrm{H}} \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{1}^{\mathrm{H}}\left(\mathbf{F}-\alpha_{1}^{2} \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{1} \mathbf{w}_{1} \mathbf{w}_{1}^{\mathrm{H}} \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{1}^{\mathrm{H}}\right)^{-1} \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{1} \mathbf{w}_{1} \\
& =\alpha_{1}^{2} P_{\mathrm{d}, 1} \mathbf{w}_{1}^{\mathrm{H}} \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{1}^{\mathrm{H}} \mathbf{F}_{1}^{-1} \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{1} \mathbf{w}_{1}=\alpha_{1}^{2} P_{\mathrm{d}, 1}\left\langle\widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{1} \mathbf{w}_{1} \mathbf{w}_{1}^{\mathrm{H}} \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{1}^{\mathrm{H}}, \mathbf{F}_{1}^{-1}\right\rangle= \\
& \alpha_{1}^{2}\left\langle\mathcal{A}_{1}\left(\widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{1} \widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{1}^{\mathrm{H}}\right), \mathbf{F}_{1}^{-1}\right\rangle=\alpha_{1}^{2}\left\langle\widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{1} \widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{1}^{\mathrm{H}}, \mathbf{C}_{\mathbf{x}_{1}} \otimes \mathbf{F}_{1}^{-1}\right\rangle= \\
& \alpha_{1}^{2} \widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{1}^{\mathrm{H}}\left(\mathbf{C}_{\mathbf{x}_{1}} \otimes \mathbf{F}_{1}^{-1}\right) \widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{1}
\end{aligned}
$$

which proves the result.

## APPENDIX C
## Proof of Theorem 2

Define the expectation of SE and SINR, by

$$
\overline{\operatorname{SE}}(\mathbf{q}, i) \triangleq \mathbb{E}\left[\operatorname{SE}\left(\mathbf{q}, i, \widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{1}\right)\right], \bar{\gamma}(\mathbf{q}, i) \triangleq \mathbb{E}\left[\gamma\left(\mathbf{q}, i, \widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{1}\right)\right]
$$

The aim is to find a deterministic equivalent expression for the instantaneous SE. First, we resort the second-order delta method to find the asymptotic distribution of the function $\mathrm{SE}=$ $\log _{2}(1+\gamma) \triangleq f(\gamma)$. Let $\gamma^{\circ}$ be the deterministic equivalent expression such that $\gamma \stackrel{\mathbf{F}_{1}}{\rightleftarrows} \gamma^{\circ}$ in the asymptotic limit. First, we write the Taylor expansion of $f(\cdot)$ around the $\gamma^{\circ}$ as follows:

$$
f(\gamma)=f\left(\gamma^{\circ}\right)+\left.\left(\gamma-\gamma^{\circ}\right) \frac{\partial f}{\partial \gamma}\right|_{\gamma=\gamma^{\circ}}+\frac{\left.\left(\gamma-\gamma^{\circ}\right)^{2}}{2} \frac{\partial^{2} f}{\partial^{2} \gamma}\right|_{\gamma=\bar{\gamma}}
$$

where $\bar{\gamma}$ lies between $\gamma$ and $\gamma^{\circ}$. We can rewrite the above relation as follows:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& f(\gamma)=f\left(\gamma^{\circ}\right)+\left(\gamma-\bar{\gamma}+\bar{\gamma}-\gamma^{\circ}\right)\left.\frac{\partial f}{\partial \gamma}\right|_{\gamma=\gamma^{\circ}}+ \\
& \left.\frac{\left(\gamma-\bar{\gamma}+\bar{\gamma}-\gamma^{\circ}\right)^{2}}{2} \frac{\partial^{2} f}{\partial^{2} \gamma}\right|_{\gamma=\bar{\gamma}}
\end{aligned}
$$

If $\gamma \xrightarrow{\mathrm{F}} \gamma^{\circ}$, then, because $|\bar{\gamma}-\gamma| \leqslant\left|\gamma^{\circ}-\gamma\right|$ and $f^{\prime \prime}(\cdot)$ is continuous, we conclude that $f^{\prime \prime}(\bar{\gamma}) \xrightarrow{\mathrm{F}} f^{\prime \prime}\left(\gamma^{\circ}\right)$ where we used the continuous mapping theorem [54]. By taking the expectation with respect to the random variable $\gamma$, we have:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathrm{E}[f(\gamma)]=f\left(\gamma^{\circ}\right)-\frac{\operatorname{var}(\gamma)}{2 \ln (2)\left(1+\gamma^{\circ}\right)^{2}}+\frac{\bar{\gamma}-\gamma^{\circ}}{\ln (2)\left(1+\gamma^{\circ}\right)} \\
& -\frac{\left(\bar{\gamma}-\gamma^{\circ}\right)^{2}}{2 \ln (2)\left(1+\gamma^{\circ}\right)^{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

where we used the second-order delta method [55] to replace $f^{\prime \prime}(\bar{\gamma})$ by $f^{\prime \prime}\left(\gamma^{\circ}\right)$.

In what follows, we show that expected SINR $\bar{\gamma}$ is well approximated by the SINR expression $\gamma^{\circ}(\mathbf{q}, i)$. This implies that

$$
\mathrm{E}[f(\gamma)] \xrightarrow{\text { a.s. }} f\left(\gamma^{\circ}\right)-\frac{\operatorname{var}(\gamma)}{2 \ln (2)\left(1+\gamma^{\circ}\right)^{2}}
$$

which is our final result. Define $\mathbf{B}=\sum_{k=2}^{K} \alpha_{k}^{2} \mathcal{A}_{k}\left(\widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{k} \widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{k}^{\mathrm{H}}\right)+\boldsymbol{\Theta}$, we can write $\mathbf{F}_{1}$ in Theorem 1 as $\mathbf{F}_{1}=\mathbf{B}+\boldsymbol{\Theta}+\rho_{\mathrm{d}} \mathbf{I}_{N_{r}}$.

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{\bar{\gamma}(\mathbf{q}, i)}{N_{r}}=\frac{1}{N_{r}} \alpha_{1}^{2}\left\langle\mathbf{C}_{\widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{1}}, \mathbf{C}_{\mathbf{x}_{1}} \otimes \mathrm{E}\left[\mathbf{F}_{1}^{-1}\right]\right\rangle^{N_{r} \rightarrow \infty} \\
& \frac{1}{N_{r}} \alpha_{1}^{2}\left\langle\mathbf{C}_{\widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{1}}, \mathbf{C}_{\mathbf{x}_{1}} \otimes \boldsymbol{\Xi}^{-1}\right\rangle \triangleq \frac{\gamma^{\circ}(\mathbf{q}, i)}{N_{r}}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\boldsymbol{\Xi} \triangleq \boldsymbol{\Gamma}+\boldsymbol{\Theta}+\rho_{\mathrm{d}} \mathbf{I}_{N_{r}}$ and $\boldsymbol{\Gamma}$ is a matrix depending on the Stieltjes transform corresponding to the empirical distribution of $\mathbf{B}$ and is determined later.

The approximation error in (69) is defined as the difference between $\bar{\gamma}(\mathbf{q}, i)$ and $\gamma^{\circ}(\mathbf{q}, i)$ given by:
$e_{N}=\frac{\alpha_{1}^{2}}{N_{r}}\left\langle\mathcal{A}_{1}\left(\mathbf{C}_{\widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{1}}\right),\left(\mathbf{B}+\rho_{\mathrm{d}} \mathbf{I}_{N_{r}}\right)^{-1}\right\rangle-\frac{\alpha_{1}^{2}}{N_{r}}\left\langle\mathcal{A}_{1}\left(\mathbf{C}_{\widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{1}}\right), \boldsymbol{\Xi}^{-1}\right\rangle$.
The aim is to show that $e_{N} \xrightarrow{N_{r} \rightarrow \infty} 0$ with high probability. First, we state the resolvent matrix identity between two matrices i.e.

$$
\mathbf{U}^{-1}-\mathbf{V}^{-1}=\mathbf{V}^{-1}(\mathbf{V}-\mathbf{U}) \mathbf{U}^{-1}, \forall \mathbf{U}, \mathbf{V}
$$

to have

$$
\left(\mathbf{B}+\rho_{\mathrm{d}} \mathbf{I}_{N_{r}}\right)^{-1}-\boldsymbol{\Xi}^{-1}=\boldsymbol{\Xi}^{-1}\left(\boldsymbol{\Xi}-\mathbf{B}-\rho_{\mathrm{d}} \mathbf{I}_{N_{r}}\right)\left(\mathbf{B}+\rho_{\mathrm{d}} \mathbf{I}_{N_{r}}\right)^{-1}
$$

The aim is to show that $e_{N} \xrightarrow{N_{r} \rightarrow \infty} 0$ with high probability. First, we state the resolvent matrix identity between two matrices i.e.

$$
\mathbf{U}^{-1}-\mathbf{V}^{-1}=\mathbf{V}^{-1}(\mathbf{V}-\mathbf{U}) \mathbf{U}^{-1}, \forall \mathbf{U}, \mathbf{V}
$$

to have

$$
\left(\mathbf{B}+\rho_{\mathrm{d}} \mathbf{I}_{N_{r}}\right)^{-1}-\boldsymbol{\Xi}^{-1}=\boldsymbol{\Xi}^{-1}\left(\boldsymbol{\Xi}-\mathbf{B}-\rho_{\mathrm{d}} \mathbf{I}_{N_{r}}\right)\left(\mathbf{B}+\rho_{\mathrm{d}} \mathbf{I}_{N_{r}}\right)^{-1}

We can proceed with (72) as follows:

$$
\begin{aligned}

& -\sum_{k=2}^{K} \alpha_{k}^{2} \boldsymbol{\Xi}^{-1} \mathcal{A}_{k}\left(\widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{k} \widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{k}^{H}\right)\left(\mathbf{B}+\rho_{\mathrm{d}} \mathbf{I}_{N_{r}}\right)^{-1}
\end{aligned}

Now, the residual $e_{N}$ in (70) becomes as

$$
e_{N}=\frac{\alpha_{1}^{2}}{N_{r}}\left\langle\mathcal{A}_{1}\left(\mathbf{C}_{\widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{1}}\right), \boldsymbol{\Xi}^{-1} \boldsymbol{\Gamma}\left(\mathbf{B}+\rho_{\mathrm{d}} \mathbf{I}_{N_{r}}\right)^{-1}\right\rangle-
$$

$$
\frac{\alpha_{1}^{2}}{N_{r}} \sum_{k=2}^{K} \alpha_{k}^{2}\left\langle\mathcal{A}_{1}\left(\mathbf{C}_{\mathbf{x}_{1}}\right), \boldsymbol{\Xi}^{-1} \mathcal{A}_{k}\left(\widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{k} \widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{k}^{\mathrm{H}}\right)\left(\mathbf{B}+\rho_{\mathrm{d}} \mathbf{I}_{N_{r}}\right)^{-1}\right\rangle

Due to the relation 53, it follows that

$\mathbf{w}_{k}^{\mathrm{H}} \mathbf{J}_{k}{ }^{\mathrm{H}}\left(\mathbf{B}+\rho_{\mathrm{d}} \mathbf{I}_{N_{r}}\right)^{-1}=\frac{\mathbf{w}_{k}^{\mathrm{H}} \mathbf{J}_{k}{ }^{\mathrm{H}}\left(\mathbf{B}_{(k)}+\rho_{\mathrm{d}} \mathbf{I}_{N_{r}}\right)^{-1}}{1+\alpha_{k}^{2} P_{\mathrm{d}, k} \mathbf{w}_{k}^{\mathrm{H}} \mathbf{J}_{k}{ }^{\mathrm{H}}\left(\mathbf{B}_{(k)}+\rho_{\mathrm{d}} \mathbf{I}_{N_{r}}\right)^{-1} \mathbf{J}_{k} \mathbf{w}_{k}}$,

By incorporating (76) and (77) into (74), the approximation error reads as:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& e_{N}=\frac{\alpha_{1}^{2}}{N_{r}} \sum_{k=2}^{K} \alpha_{k}^{2} \frac{\widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{k}^{\mathrm{H}}\left(\mathbf{C}_{\mathbf{x}_{k}} \otimes\left(\mathbf{B}_{(k)}+\rho_{\mathrm{d}} \mathbf{I}_{N_{r}}\right)^{-1} \mathcal{A}_{1}\left(\mathbf{C}_{\widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{1}}\right) \boldsymbol{\Xi}^{-1}\right) \widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{k}}{1+\alpha_{k}^{2} \widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{k}^{\mathrm{H}} \mathbf{C}_{\mathbf{x}_{k}} \otimes\left(\mathbf{B}_{(k)}+\rho_{\mathrm{d}} \mathbf{I}_{N_{r}}\right)^{-1} \widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{k}}}- \\
& \frac{\alpha_{1}^{2}}{N_{r}} \sum_{k=2}^{K} \alpha_{k}^{2} \frac{\left\langle\mathbf{C}_{\widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{k}}, \mathbf{C}_{\mathbf{x}_{k}} \otimes \boldsymbol{\Xi}^{-1} \mathcal{A}_{1}\left(\mathbf{C}_{\widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{1}}\right)\left(\mathbf{B}+\rho_{\mathrm{d}} \mathbf{I}_{N_{r}}\right)^{-1}\right\rangle}{1+\alpha_{k}^{2} N_{r} m \mathbf{C}_{\widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{k}}, \mathbf{B}\left(\rho_{\mathrm{d}}\right)} \triangleq \frac{1}{K-1} \sum_{k=2}^{K} \alpha_{k}^{2} d_{k}

Lemma 4. Let $\mathbf{J} \in \mathbb{C}^{N_{r} \times N_{t}}, \mathbf{B}$ be a Hermitian non-negative definite matrix and $\mathbf{C}$ is of size $N_{t} \times N_{t}$. Then for $t>0$ and $\rho_{\mathrm{d}}>0$, we have: $\left|\frac{1}{1+t\left\langle\mathbf{J C J}^{H},\left(\mathbf{B}+\rho_{\mathrm{d}} \mathbf{I}\right)^{-1}\right\rangle}\right| \leqslant 1$.
It then follows that

where we used Lemma 4. $\left(\mathbf{B}_{(k)}+\rho_{\mathrm{d}} \mathbf{I}_{N_{r}}\right)^{-1}$ is the Stieltjes transform of a finite measure in $\mathbb{C}^{-}$, so by [57, Theorem 3.2], we have

$$
