& \sum_{k=2}^{K} \alpha_{k}^{4} N_{r} \frac{\left|m \mathbf{C}_{\tilde{\mathbf{h}}_{\mathrm{k}}}, \mathbf{B}_{(k)}\left(\rho_{\mathrm{d}}\right)-m \mathbf{C}_{\tilde{\mathbf{h}}_{\mathrm{k}}}, \mathbf{B}\left(\rho_{\mathrm{d}}\right)\right|}{\left(1+\alpha_{k}^{2} N_{r} m \mathbf{C}_{\tilde{\mathbf{h}}_{\mathrm{k}}}, \mathbf{B}_{(k)}\left(\rho_{\mathrm{d}}\right)\right)\left(1+\alpha_{k}^{2} N_{r} m \mathbf{C}_{\tilde{\mathbf{h}}_{\mathrm{k}}}, \mathbf{B}\left(\rho_{\mathrm{d}}\right)\right)} \leqslant \frac{\mu_{k}^{\prime 4}}{\left|\rho_{\mathrm{d}}\right|}, \\
& \text { where we used [58, Lemma 2.1], and } \\
& \left\|\mathcal{A}_{k}\left(\mathbf{C}_{\tilde{\mathbf{h}}_{\mathrm{k}}}\right)\right\|=\sup _{\substack{\mathbf{y} \neq 0 \\ \mathbf{y} \neq 0}} \frac{\left\langle\mathcal{A}_{k}\left(\mathbf{C}_{\tilde{\mathbf{h}}_{\mathrm{k}}}\right) \mathbf{y}, \mathbf{x}\right\rangle}{\|\mathbf{x}\|_{2}\|\mathbf{y}\|_{2}}=\sup _{\substack{\mathbf{y} \neq 0 \\ \mathbf{y} \neq 0}} \frac{\left\langle\mathcal{A}_{k}\left(\mathbf{C}_{\tilde{\mathbf{h}}_{\mathrm{k}}}\right), \mathbf{x y}^{H}\right\rangle}{\|\mathbf{x}\|_{2}\|\mathbf{y}\|_{2}} \\
& =\sup _{\substack{\mathbf{x} \neq 0 \\ \mathbf{y} \neq 0}} \frac{\left\langle\mathbf{C}_{\tilde{\mathbf{h}}_{\mathrm{k}}}, \mathbf{x y}^{H} \otimes \mathbf{C}_{\mathbf{x}_{k}}\right\rangle}{\|\mathbf{x}\|_{2}\|\mathbf{y}\|_{2}} \leqslant \operatorname{tr}\left(\mathbf{C}_{\tilde{\mathbf{h}}_{\mathrm{k}}}\right)\left\|\mathbf{C}_{\mathbf{x}_{k}}\right\| \leqslant \frac{\Omega_{1}^{2} \Omega_{2} L_{k}}{N} \triangleq \mu_{k}^{\prime}, \\
& \text { in which } \mathbf{C}_{\tilde{\mathbf{h}}_{\mathrm{k}}}=\boldsymbol{\Psi}_{\tilde{\mathbf{h}}_{\mathrm{k}}} \mathbf{C}_{\zeta_{k}} \boldsymbol{\Psi}_{\tilde{\mathbf{h}}_{\mathrm{k}}}^{H} \text { and we made the following }
\end{aligned}
$$

assumptions:

$$
\left\|\boldsymbol{\Psi}_{\tilde{\mathbf{h}}_{\mathrm{k}}}\right\| \leqslant \Omega_{1},\left\|\mathbf{C}_{\zeta_{k}}\right\| \leqslant \frac{\Omega_{2}}{N}, \operatorname{tr}\left(\mathbf{C}_{\zeta_{k}}\right) \leqslant \frac{L_{k} \Omega_{2}}{N} \quad \forall k
$$

Here, $L_{k}$ is the number of paths between user $k$ and the BS. Furthermore, it holds that

$$
\left|m \mathbf{C}_{\tilde{\mathbf{h}}_{\mathrm{k}}}, \mathbf{B}_{(k)}\left(\rho_{\mathrm{d}}\right)-m \mathbf{C}_{\tilde{\mathbf{h}}_{\mathrm{k}}}, \mathbf{B}\left(\rho_{\mathrm{d}}\right)\right| \leqslant \frac{\mu_{k}^{\prime}}{N_{r}\left|\rho_{\mathrm{d}}\right|}
$$

and by [57, Corollary 3.1] when $K \rightarrow \infty$,

$$
\left|\frac{1}{K-1} \sum_{k=2}^{K} \frac{\alpha_{k}^{2}}{1+\alpha_{k}^{2} N m \mathbf{C}_{\tilde{\mathbf{h}}_{\mathrm{k}}}, \mathbf{B}_{(k)}\left(\rho_{\mathrm{d}}\right)}\right| \leqslant \mu_{k}^{\prime}
$$

Thus, this leads to finding an upper-bound in (90) which finally reads as

$$
\left\|\mathbf{E}^{(-1)}-\mathbf{E}_{(k)}^{(-1)}\right\| \leqslant \mu_{k}^{\prime 4} \frac{1}{\left|\rho_{\mathrm{d}}\right|^{3}}
$$

Now by having this in mind, together with (89), (88) reads as follows:

$$
\left|d_{k}^{(1)}\right| \leqslant \frac{\alpha_{1}^{2} \mathrm{E}\left\|\tilde{\mathbf{h}}_{k}\right\|_{2}^{2}}{\alpha_{k}^{2}} \frac{P_{0, k} \mu_{1}^{\prime} \mu_{k}^{\prime}}{N_{t} N_{r}\left|\rho_{\mathrm{d}}\right|^{4}}
$$

To bound $\mathbb{E}\left\|\tilde{\mathbf{h}}_{k}\right\|_{2}^{2}$ in the above relation, we use the following lemma which provides an adapted version of [45, Lemma B.26], showing that non-centered quadratic matrix forms concentrate around their expectation.

Lemma 5. Let $\mathbf{A} \in \mathbb{C}^{N \times N}$ be a deterministic matrix and $\tilde{\mathbf{h}}=\tilde{\mathbf{h}}+\Delta \mathbf{a} \in \mathbb{C}^{N \times 1}$ where $\mathbf{a} \in \mathbb{C}^{r}$ is a random vector of zero mean with i.i.d. elements and variance $\frac{1}{N}$ and $\Delta \in$ $\mathbb{C}^{N \times r}$ is a deterministic matrix with bounded spectral norm that is $\|\Delta\| \leqslant Q$. Also, assume that the cross-correlations and auto-correlations satisfy $\left|\mathbb{E}\left\{|a(i) a(j)|^{2}\right\}\right| \leqslant \nu_{4} \forall i, j$ and $\left|\mathbb{E}\left\{|a(i)|^{2}\right\}\right| \leqslant \nu_{2} \forall i$. Then, we have:

$$
\mathbb{E}\left|\tilde{\mathbf{h}}^{H} \mathbf{A} \tilde{\mathbf{h}}-\left\langle\mathbf{R}_{\tilde{\mathbf{h}}}, \mathbf{A}\right\rangle\right| \leqslant C \frac{1}{N}\left(\nu_{2}+\sqrt{\nu_{4}}\right) Q^{2}\|\mathbf{A}\|_{F}
$$

for some constant $C$.
Now, by using Lemma 5, (97) reads as follows:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathbb{E}\left|d_{k}^{(1)}\right| \leqslant \frac{\alpha_{1}^{2} P_{0, k} \mu_{1}^{\prime} \mu_{k}^{\prime}}{\alpha_{k}^{2} N_{t} N_{r}\left|\rho_{\mathrm{d}}\right|^{4}}\left(\mathbb{E}\left\|\tilde{\mathbf{h}}_{k}\right\|_{2}^{2}-\operatorname{tr}\left(\mathbf{C}_{\tilde{\mathbf{h}}_{\mathrm{k}}}\right)\right|+\operatorname{tr}\left(\mathbf{C}_{\tilde{\mathbf{h}}_{\mathrm{k}}}\right)\right) \leqslant \\
& \frac{\alpha_{1}^{2} P_{0, k} \mu_{1}^{\prime} \mu_{k}^{\prime}}{\alpha_{k}^{2} N_{r} N_{r}\left|\rho_{\mathrm{d}}\right|^{4}}\left(c^{\prime} \frac{\Omega_{1}^{2} \Omega_{2}}{\sqrt{N}}+\frac{\Omega_{1}^{2} \Omega_{2} L_{k}}{N}\right) \frac{N_{r} \rightarrow \infty}{N} 0
\end{aligned}
$$

where we used (93) and Lemma 5 and

$$
\mathbb{E}\left\|\left\|\tilde{\mathbf{h}}_{k}\right\|_{2}^{2}-\mathbf{C}_{\tilde{\mathbf{h}}_{\mathrm{k}}}\right\| \leqslant c^{\prime} \frac{\Omega_{1}^{2} \Omega_{2}}{\sqrt{N}}
$$

For $d^{(2)}$ bound based on Lemmas 4 and 5 , we have:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathbb{E}\left|d_{k}^{(2)}\right| \leqslant \frac{c^{\prime} \alpha_{k}^{2}}{\alpha_{k}^{2} N_{r} N} \Omega_{1}^{2} \Omega_{2}\left\|\mathbf{C}_{\mathbf{x}_{k}} \otimes\left(\mathbf{B}_{(k)}+\rho_{\mathrm{d}} \mathbf{I}_{N_{r}}\right)^{-1} \mathcal{A}_{1}\left(\mathbf{C}_{\tilde{\mathbf{h}}_{\mathrm{k}}}\right) \mathbf{E}_{(k)}^{-1}\right\|_{F} \\
& \leqslant \frac{c^{\prime} \alpha_{1}^{2}}{\alpha_{k}^{2} N_{r} N} \Omega_{1}^{2} \Omega_{2} P_{0, k}\left\|\left(\mathbf{B}_{(k)}+\rho_{\mathrm{d}} \mathbf{I}_{N_{r}}\right)^{-1}\right\|\left\|\mathbf{E}^{(-1)}_{(k)}\right\|\left\|\mathcal{A}\left(\mathbf{C}_{\tilde{\mathbf{h}}}\right)\right\|_{F} \\
& \leqslant \frac{c^{\prime} \alpha_{1}^{2} \Omega_{1}^{2} \Omega_{2}}{\alpha_{k}^{2} \sqrt{N_{r} N\left|\rho_{\mathrm{d}}\right|^{2}}} \mu_{1}^{\prime} \frac{N_{r} \rightarrow \infty}{N} 0
\end{aligned}
$$

for some constant $c^{\prime}>0$. To obtain a bound for $d_{k}^{(3)}$, we use Lemmas 4 and 5 which leads to

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathbb{E} d_{k}^{(3)} \leqslant \frac{\alpha_{1}^{2}}{N_{r} \alpha_{k}^{2}}\left\langle\mathbf{C}_{\tilde{\mathbf{h}}_{\mathrm{k}}}, \mathbf{C}_{\mathbf{x}_{k}} \otimes\right. \\
& {\left[\left(\mathbf{E}_{(k)}^{-1}-\mathbf{E}^{(-1)}\right) \mathcal{A}_{1}\left(\mathbf{C}_{\tilde{\mathbf{h}}_{k}}\right)\left(\mathbf{B}_{(k)}+\rho_{\mathrm{d}} \mathbf{I}_{N_{r}}\right)^{-1}+\mathbf{E}^{(-1)} \mathcal{A}_{1}\left(\mathbf{C}_{\tilde{\mathbf{h}}_{k}}\right)\right.} \\
& \left.\left(\left(\mathbf{B}_{(k)}+\rho_{\mathrm{d}} \mathbf{I}_{N_{r}}\right)^{-1}-\left(\mathbf{B}+\rho_{\mathrm{d}} \mathbf{I}_{N_{r}}\right)^{-1}\right)\right)\right] \rangle \leqslant}
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{\alpha_{1}^{2}}{N_{r} \alpha_{k}^{2}} \mu_{k}^{\prime}\left(\left\|\left(\boldsymbol{\Xi}_{(k)}^{\prime-1}-\boldsymbol{\Xi}^{\prime-1}\right)\right\|\left(\mathbf{B}_{(k)}+\rho_{\mathrm{d}} \mathbf{I}_{N_{r}}\right)^{-1}\left\|\operatorname{tr}\left(\mathcal{A}\left(\mathbf{C}_{\widehat{\mathbf{h}}}\right)\right)+\right.\right. \\
& \left.\left.\left\|\boldsymbol{\Xi}^{\prime-1} \mu_{1}^{\prime}+\operatorname{tr}\left(\left(\mathbf{B}_{(k)}+\rho_{\mathrm{d}} \mathbf{I}_{N_{r}}\right)^{-1}-\left(\mathbf{B}+\rho_{\mathrm{d}} \mathbf{I}_{N_{r}}\right)^{-1}\right)\right)\right\}\right) \leqslant \\
& \frac{\alpha_{1}^{2} \mu_{1}^{\prime}}{N_{r} \alpha_{k}^{2}}\left(\mu_{k}^{\prime} \frac{1}{\left\|\rho_{\mathrm{d}}\right\|^{2}} \frac{P_{\mathrm{d}}}{N_{t}}\left(\frac{\Omega_{1}^{2} \Omega_{2} L_{1}}{N}\right)+\frac{\mu_{1}^{\prime}}{\left\|\rho_{\mathrm{d}}\right\|^{2}}\right) \xrightarrow{N_{r} \rightarrow \infty} 0
\end{aligned}
$$

Lastly, $d_{k}^{(4)}$ can be bounded as:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathrm{E} d_{k}^{(4)} \leqslant \frac{\alpha_{1}^{2} \alpha_{1}^{2}}{\alpha_{k}^{2}}\left\|\mathbf{C}_{\widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{k}}, \mathbf{C}_{\mathbf{x}_{k}} \otimes \boldsymbol{\Xi}^{\prime-1} \mathcal{A}_{1}\left(\mathbf{C}_{\widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{1}}\right)\left(\mathbf{B}+\rho_{\mathrm{d}} \mathbf{I}_{N_{r}}\right)^{-1}\right\| \\
& \left\|\widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{1}^{H} \mathbf{C}_{\mathbf{x}_{k}} \otimes\left(\mathbf{B}+\rho_{\mathrm{d}} \mathbf{I}_{N_{r}}\right)^{-1} \widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{k}-N_{r} m_{\mathbf{C}_{\widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{k}}, \mathbf{B}_{(k)}}\left(\rho_{\mathrm{d}}\right)\right\| \leqslant \\
& \frac{\mu_{k}^{\prime} \alpha_{1}^{2}}{N_{r}\left\|\rho_{\mathrm{d}}\right\|^{2}} \frac{P_{\mathrm{d}}}{N_{t}}\left(\frac{\Omega_{1}^{2} \Omega_{2} L_{1}}{N}\right) e^{\prime} \frac{\Omega_{1}^{2} \Omega_{2} \sqrt{P_{\mathrm{d}, k} \sqrt{N_{r}}}}{N \alpha_{k}^{2}\left\|\rho_{\mathrm{d}}\right\|} \xrightarrow{N_{r} \rightarrow \infty} 0
\end{aligned}
$$

where we used Lemma 5. As $N_{r}$ tends to infinity, $e_{N}$ in (83) vanishes with high probability. Let $\omega^{\star}$ represent the final solution of the fixed-point equation (30) to which it converges. Consequently, as the number of receive antennas $N_{r}$ approaches infinity, the expression $\left|N_{r} m_{\mathbf{C}_{\mathbf{h}}, \mathbf{B}}\left(\rho_{\mathrm{d}}\right)-\omega^{\star}\right|$ tends to zero with high probability.

For obtaining the deterministic equivalent of the variance term i.e. $\operatorname{var}(\gamma)$, we have:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \operatorname{var}(\gamma)=\operatorname{var}\left(\alpha_{1}^{2} \widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{1}^{H}\left(\mathbf{C}_{\mathbf{x}_{1}} \otimes \mathbf{F}_{1}^{-1}\right) \widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{1}\right)= \\
& 2 \alpha_{1}^{4} \operatorname{tr}\left(\left(\mathbf{C}_{\mathbf{x}_{1}} \otimes \mathbf{F}_{1}^{-1}\right) \mathbf{C}_{\widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{1}}\left(\mathbf{C}_{\mathbf{x}_{1}} \otimes \mathbf{F}_{1}^{-1}\right) \mathbf{C}_{\widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{1}}\right)= \\
& 2 \alpha_{1}^{4} \operatorname{tr}\left(\mathbf{F}_{1}^{-1} \mathcal{A}_{1}\left(\mathbf{C}_{\widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{1}}\right) \mathbf{F}_{1}^{-1} \mathcal{A}_{1}\left(\mathbf{C}_{\widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{1}}\right)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where we used [59, Eq. (379)] in the last equation. Now, by leveraging the result of [34, Proof of Theorem 2], the deterministic equivalent expression for variance of the SINR is obtained as in (27).

## APPENDIX D
## Proof of Proposition 3

Assume that $\mathbf{w}=\mathbf{w}^{i}$ is the beamforming vector corresponding to the symbol time $i$. Let $\mathbf{W} \triangleq \mathbf{w w}^{H}$ and $\mathbf{Z}_{1} \triangleq$ $\mathcal{A}_{1}\left(\mathbf{C}_{\widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{1}}\right)$. Consider the function $f_{1}\left(\mathbf{Z}_{1}\right) \triangleq \log _{2}\left(1+\left\langle\mathbf{Z}_{1}, \mathbf{T}\right\rangle\right)-$ $\frac{\left\langle\mathbf{Z}_{1}, \mathbf{T} \mathbf{Z}_{1} \mathbf{T}\right\rangle}{2 \ln (2)\left(1+\left\langle\mathbf{Z}_{1}, \mathbf{T}\right\rangle\right)^{2}}$. The derivative of the latter function with respect to the positive definite matrix $\mathbf{W}$ is obtained by chain rule lemma $\frac{\partial f_{1}\left(\mathbf{Z}_{1}\right)}{\partial \mathbf{W}}=\frac{\partial f_{1}\left(\mathbf{Z}_{1}\right)}{\partial \mathbf{Z}_{1}} \frac{\partial \mathbf{Z}_{1}}{\partial \mathbf{W}}$ and the following relation:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{\partial f_{1}\left(\mathbf{Z}_{1}\right)}{\partial \mathbf{Z}_{1}}=\frac{\mathbf{T}}{\ln (2)\left(1+\left\langle\mathbf{Z}_{1}, \mathbf{T}\right\rangle\right)}-\frac{2 \mathbf{T} \mathbf{Z}_{1} \mathbf{T}}{2 \ln (2)\left(1+\left\langle\mathbf{Z}_{1}, \mathbf{T}\right\rangle\right)^{2}}+\frac{2 \mathbf{T}\left(\left\langle\mathbf{Z}_{1}, \mathbf{T} \mathbf{Z}_{1} \mathbf{T}\right\rangle\right)}{2 \ln (2)\left(1+\left\langle\mathbf{Z}_{1}, \mathbf{T}\right\rangle\right)^{2}} \\
& =\frac{\left(1+\left\langle\mathbf{Z}_{1}, \mathbf{T}\right\rangle\right)^{2} \mathbf{T}-\mathbf{T} \mathbf{Z}_{1} \mathbf{T}\left(1+\left\langle\mathbf{Z}_{1}, \mathbf{T}\right\rangle\right)+2 \mathbf{T}\left(\left\langle\mathbf{Z}_{1}, \mathbf{T} \mathbf{Z}_{1} \mathbf{T}\right\rangle\right)}{\ln (2)\left(1+\left\langle\mathbf{Z}_{1}, \mathbf{T}\right\rangle\right)^{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Since $\mathbf{T}$ and $\mathbf{Z}_{1}$ are non-negative definite, $\operatorname{tr}\left(\mathbf{T Z}_{1} \mathbf{T Z}_{1}\right)$ is nonnegative. It remains to prove the positive definiteness of $\left(1+\left\langle\mathbf{Z}_{1}, \mathbf{T}\right\rangle\right) \mathbf{I}-\mathbf{T} \mathbf{Z}_{1}$. For arbitrary vector $\mathbf{x} \in \mathbb{C}^{N_{r} \times 1}$, we have:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathbf{x}^{H}\left(\left(1+\left\langle\mathbf{Z}_{1}, \mathbf{T}\right\rangle\right) \mathbf{I}-\mathbf{T} \mathbf{Z}_{1}\right) \mathbf{x}= \\
& \|\mathbf{x}\|_{2}^{2}+\mathbf{x}^{H} \operatorname{tr}\left(\mathbf{T} \mathbf{Z}_{1}\right) \mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}^{H} \mathbf{T} \mathbf{Z}_{1} \mathbf{x} \geqslant \\
& \|\mathbf{x}\|_{2}^{2}+\|\mathbf{x}\|_{2}^{2} \operatorname{tr}\left(\mathbf{T} \mathbf{Z}_{1}\right)-\left\|\mathbf{T} \mathbf{Z}_{1}\right\| \|\mathbf{x}\|_{2}^{2}>0
\end{aligned}
$$

where in the last relation, we used the fact that the sum of singular values of a matrix is greater than the maximum singular value. This demonstrates that $f_{1}\left(\mathbf{Z}_{1}\right)$ increases with respect to $\mathbf{Z}_{1}$. Since $\frac{\partial \mathbf{Z}_{1}}{\partial \mathbf{W}}=\mathbf{C}_{\widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{1}}$ and nonnegative definite, this leads to the conclusion that the function $f_{1}$ is non-decreasing in $\mathbf{W}$. This proves that maximizing $\mathrm{SE}^{\circ}$ with respect to $\mathbf{W} \triangleq \mathbf{w w}^{H}$ is equivalent to maximizing $\left\langle\mathbf{C}_{\mathbf{h}_{1}}, \mathbf{W} \otimes \mathbf{T}\right\rangle$. Thus,
the optimum $\mathbf{w w}^{H}$ is the one that maximizes the term inside inner product.

$$
\left\langle\mathbf{C}_{\widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{1}}, \mathbf{W} \otimes \mathbf{T}\right\rangle=\sum_{i, l=1}^{N_{r}} T(i, l)\left\langle\mathbf{C}_{\widehat{\mathbf{h}}}^{i, l}, \mathbf{W}\right\rangle
$$

where the second term is obtained by partitioning $\mathbf{C}_{z}$ as in (38) and using Kronecker product properties. Moreover, the adjoint operator of $\mathcal{G}(\cdot)$ is given by

$$
\left\langle\mathcal{G}\left(\mathbf{C}_{\widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{1}}\right), \mathbf{T}\right\rangle=\left\langle\mathbf{C}_{\widehat{\mathbf{h}}}, \mathcal{G}^{\mathrm{Adj}}(\mathbf{T})\right\rangle
$$

The optimal matrix $\mathbf{W}$ is acquired through performing Singular Value Decomposition (SVD) on $\mathcal{G}\left(\mathbf{R}_{\mathbf{s}}\right)$. Singular vectors associated with the maximum singular value are selectively retained. Consequently, the optimal vector $\mathbf{w}$ corresponds to the singular vector responsible for achieving this maximum value.

## APPENDIX E
## Proof of Proposition 2

To find the optimal MMSE estimate of the data symbol $s(i)$ of the tagged user, we need to solve the following optimization problem:

$$
\mathbf{g}^{\star}(i) \triangleq \underset{\mathbf{g} \in \mathbb{C}^{N_{r} \times 1}}{\arg \min } \mathrm{E}_{s(i) \mid \widehat{\mathbf{h}}(i)}\left|\mathbf{g}^{H} \mathbf{y}_{\mathrm{d}}-s(i)\right|^{2}
$$

Since the objective function in the unconstrained optimization problem is convex, we can determine the optimal solution by calculating the derivative of the squared objective function with respect to $\mathbf{g}$ and setting it to zero. This process yields the following relationship:

$$
\frac{\partial \mathrm{E}_{s\left(\widehat{\mathbf{h}}(i)\right)}\left|\mathbf{g}^{H} \mathbf{y}_{d}(i)-s\right|^{2}}{\partial \mathbf{g}}=2 \mathrm{E}\left\{\left(\mathbf{g}^{H} \mathbf{y}_{\mathrm{d}}(i)-s\right) \mathbf{y}_{\mathrm{d}}(i)^{\mathrm{H}}\right\}=\mathbf{0}
$$

which results in the following solution for the optimum receiver:

$$
\mathbf{g}^{\star}(i)=\left(\mathrm{E}\left\{\mathbf{y}_{\mathrm{d}} \mathbf{y}_{\mathrm{d}}^{H} \mid \widehat{\mathbf{h}}(i)\right\}\right)^{-1} \mathrm{E}\left\{s \mathbf{y}_{\mathrm{d}}^{H} \mid \widehat{\mathbf{h}}(i)\right\}
$$

The latter solution requires us to explicitly calculate the expressions $\mathrm{E}\left\{s \mathbf{y}_{\mathrm{d}}^{H} \mid \widehat{\mathbf{h}}(i)\right\}$ and $\mathrm{E}\left\{\mathbf{y}_{\mathrm{d}} \mathbf{y}_{\mathrm{d}}^{H} \mid \widehat{\mathbf{h}}(i)\right\}$. For $\mathrm{E}\left\{s \mathbf{y}_{\mathrm{d}}^{H} \mid \widehat{\mathbf{h}}(i)\right\}$, it follows that

$$
\mathrm{E}\left\{s \mathbf{y}_{\mathrm{d}}^{H} \mid \widehat{\mathbf{h}}(i)\right\}=\alpha \sqrt{P_{\mathrm{d}}} \mathbf{w}^{\mathrm{H}} \mathrm{E}\left\{\mathbf{h}(i)^{\mathrm{H}} \mid \widehat{\mathbf{h}}(i)\right\}
$$

where we used Equation (3), the data symbol of the tagged user is zero mean and the data symbols of users are independent from each other. To calculate $\mathrm{Ey}_{\mathrm{d}} \mathbf{y}_{\mathrm{d}}^{H}$, it is convenient to first rewrite $\mathbf{y}_{\mathrm{d}}(i)$ in (3) as follows:

$$
\mathbf{y}_{\mathrm{d}}(i)=\sum_{k=1}^{K} \alpha_{k}\left(\mathbf{x}_{k}^{H} \otimes \mathbf{I}\right) \mathbf{h}_{k}(i)+\mathbf{n}_{d}(i)
$$

Then, by assuming that $\left\{\mathbf{x}_{k}\right\}_{k=1}^{K}$ are zero mean and independent from each other, each element of $\mathrm{E} \mathbf{y}_{\mathrm{d}} \mathbf{y}_{\mathrm{d}}^{H}$ can be calculated as follows:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathrm{E}\left\{y_{j} y_{l}^{*} \mid \widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{k}(i)\right\}= \\
& \sum_{k=1}^{K} \alpha_{k}^{2} P_{d k}\left\langle\mathrm{E}\left\{\mathbf{h}_{k}(i) \mathbf{h}_{k}(i)^{H} \mid \widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{k}(i)\right\}, \mathbf{w}_{k} \mathbf{w}_{k}^{H} \otimes \mathbf{e}_{l} \mathbf{e}_{j}^{H}\right\rangle+\sigma_{d}^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

Define $\mathbf{D}_{k} \triangleq \mathbb{E}\left\{\mathbf{h}_{k}(i) \mathbf{h}_{k}(i)^{H} \mid \widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{k}(i)\right\} \in \mathbb{C}^{N \times N}$ and also $\mathbf{D}_{k}^{\prime} \triangleq$ $\mathbf{P}_{c}^{H} \mathbf{D} \mathbf{P}_{c}$ where $\mathbf{P}_{c}$ is the commutation matrix. Write $\mathbf{D}_{k}$ in the form of a matrix with blocks that is divided into submatrices $\mathbf{D}_{k}^{i, l} \in \mathbb{C}^{N_{i} \times N_{t}}$ (see Equation (20)). Then, (114) can be rewritten as below:

$$
\mathbb{E}\left\{y_{j} y_{l}^{*} \mid \widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{k}(i)\right\}=\sum_{k=1}^{K} \alpha_{k}^{2} P_{d, k}\left\langle\mathbf{D}_{k}^{\prime(j, l)}, \mathbf{w}_{k} \mathbf{w}_{k}^{H}\right\rangle+\sigma_{d}^{2}
$$

which then can be collected to form:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathbb{E} \mathbf{y}_{\mathrm{d}} \mathbf{y}_{\mathrm{d}}^{H}=\left[\begin{array}{ccc}
\mathbb{E}\left|y_{1}\right|^{2} & \ldots & \mathbb{E} y_{1} y_{N_{r}}^{\star} \\
\vdots & \ddots & \ldots \\
\mathbb{E} y_{N_{r}} y_{1}^{*} & \ldots & \mathbb{E}\left|y_{N_{r}}\right|^{2}
\end{array}\right]= \\
& \sum_{k=1}^{K} \alpha_{k}^{2}\left[\begin{array}{ccc}
\left\langle\mathbf{D}_{k}^{\prime(1,1)}, \mathbf{C}_{\mathbf{x}_{k}}\right\rangle & \ldots & \left\langle\mathbf{D}_{k}^{\prime\left(1, N_{r}\right)}, \mathbf{C}_{\mathbf{x}_{k}}\right\rangle \\
\vdots & \ddots & \cdots \\
\left\langle\mathbf{D}_{k}^{\prime\left(N_{r}, 1\right)}, \mathbf{C}_{\mathbf{x}_{k}}\right\rangle & \ldots & \left\langle\mathbf{D}_{k}^{\prime\left(N_{r}, N_{r}\right)}, \mathbf{C}_{\mathbf{x}_{k}}\right\rangle
\end{array}\right]+\sigma_{d}^{2} \mathbf{I}_{N_{r}}, \\
& \text { which according to the definition of the linear operator } \\
& \mathcal{A}_{k}\left(\mathbf{D}_{k}\right): \mathbb{C}^{N \times N} \rightarrow \mathbb{C}^{N_{r} \times N_{r}} \text { results in } \\
& \mathbb{E}\left\{\mathbf{y}_{\mathrm{d}} \mathbf{y}_{\mathrm{d}}^{H} \mid \widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{k}(i)\right\}=\sum_{k=1}^{K} \alpha_{k}^{2} \mathcal{A}_{k}\left(\mathbf{D}_{k}\right)+\sigma_{d}^{2} \mathbf{I}_{N_{r}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Now, it remains to calculate $\mathbf{D}_{k}$ which is obtained as follows:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathbf{D}_{k} \triangleq \mathbb{E}\left\{\mathbf{h}_{k}(i) \mathbf{h}_{k}(i)^{H} \mid \widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{k}(i)\right\}=\mathbf{C}_{\mathbf{h}_{k}(i) \mid \widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{k}(i)}+ \\
& \mathbb{E}\left\{\mathbf{h}_{k}(i) \mid \widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{k}(i)\right\} \mathbb{E}\left\{\mathbf{h}_{k}(i) \mid \widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{k}(i)\right\}^{H}
\end{aligned}
$$

In what follows, we aim to obtain two terms in the above expression, i.e, $\mathbb{E}\left\{\mathbf{h}_{k}(i) \mid \widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{k}(i)\right\}$ and $\mathbf{C}_{\mathbf{h}_{k}(i) \mid \widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{k}(i)}$. First, since $\mathbf{h}_{k}(i)$ is assumed to have zero-mean Rayleigh distribution, it can be approximated by Gaussian distribution and thus $\mathbf{h}_{k}(i)$ and $\widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{k}(i)$ are approximately jointly Gaussian, we can obtain closed-form solutions for the conditional mean and covariance as follows:

$$
\begin{gathered}
\mathbb{E}\left\{\mathbf{h}_{k}(i) \mid \widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{k}(i)\right\}=\mathbf{C}_{\mathbf{h}_{k}(i), \widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{k}(i)} \mathbf{C}_{\widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{k}(i)}^{-1} \widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{k}(i) \\
\mathbf{C}_{\mathbf{h}_{k}(i) \mid \widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{k}(i)}=\mathbf{C}_{\mathbf{h}_{k}(i)}-\mathbf{C}_{\mathbf{h}_{k}(i), \widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{k}(i)} \mathbf{C}_{\widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{k}(i)}^{-1} \mathbf{C}_{\widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{k}(i), \mathbf{h}_{k}(i)}
\end{gathered}
$$

Due to the fact that the MMSE estimation error is orthogonal to any function of the measurements and the zero-mean assumption of the channel, we have that

$$
\mathbb{E}\left\{\left(\mathbf{h}_{k}(i)-\widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{k}(i)\right) \widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{k}(i)^{H}\right\}=\mathbf{0}
$$

This leads to

$$
\mathbb{E}\left\{\mathbf{h}_{k}(i) \mid \widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{k}(i)\right\}=\widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{k}(i)
$$

and

$$
\mathbf{C}_{\mathbf{h}_{k}(i) \mid \widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{k}(i)}=\mathbf{C}_{\mathbf{h}_{k}(i)}-\mathbf{C}_{\widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{k}(i)} \triangleq \mathbf{Q}_{k}
$$

Replacing the above equations into (118), we reach:

$$
\mathbf{D}_{k}=\mathbf{Q}_{k}+\widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{k}(i) \widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{k}^{\mathrm{H}}(i)
$$

Thus, by having $\mathbf{D}_{k}$ in (124), the expression $\mathbb{E}\left\{\mathbf{y}_{\mathrm{d}} \mathbf{y}_{\mathrm{d}}^{\mathrm{H}} \mid \widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{k}(i)\right\}$
in (117) can be calculated. Also for $\mathbb{E}\left\{s \mathbf{y}_{\mathrm{d}}^{\mathrm{H}} \mid \widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{k}(i)\right\}$, we can use (122) to have:

$$
\mathbb{E}\left\{s \mathbf{y}_{\mathrm{d}}^{H} \mid \widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{k}(i)\right\}=\alpha \sqrt{P_{d}} \mathbf{w}_{1}^{\mathrm{H}} \mathbf{v e c}^{-H}\left(\widehat{\mathbf{h}}_{k}(i)\right)
$$

The latter equation together with (117) gives the final result in Proposition 2

## APPENDIX F
## Proof of Lemma 4

Let $\mathbf{B}=\mathbf{U}^{H} \boldsymbol{\Lambda} \mathbf{U}$ and $\mathbf{C}=\mathbf{V}^{H} \boldsymbol{\Sigma} \mathbf{V}$ be the eigenvalue decomposition of $\mathbf{B}$ and $\mathbf{C}$ where $\mathbf{U}$ and $\mathbf{V}$ are some orthonormal matrices. It then follows that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left\langle\mathbf{M C M}^{H},\left(\mathbf{B}+\rho_{\mathrm{d}} \mathbf{I}\right)^{-1}\right\rangle=\left\langle\mathcal{A}\left(\mathbf{z z}^{H}\right),\left(\mathbf{B}+\rho_{\mathrm{d}} \mathbf{I}\right)^{-1}\right\rangle= \\
& \left\langle\mathbf{z z}^{H}, \mathbf{C} \otimes\left(\mathbf{B}+\rho_{\mathrm{d}} \mathbf{I}\right)^{-1}\right\rangle
\end{aligned}
$$

We can proceed by applying the eigenvalue decomposition of $\mathbf{B}$ and $\mathbf{C}$ to have :

$$
\begin{aligned}
& f\left(\rho_{\mathrm{d}}\right)=\left\langle\mathbf{M C M}^{H},\left(\mathbf{B}+\rho_{\mathrm{d}} \mathbf{I}\right)^{-1}\right\rangle= \\
& \widehat{\mathbf{h}}^{H}\left(\mathbf{V}^{H} \boldsymbol{\Sigma} \mathbf{V} \otimes\left(\mathbf{U}^{H} \boldsymbol{\Lambda} \mathbf{U}+\rho_{\mathrm{d}} \mathbf{I}\right)^{-1}\right) \widehat{\mathbf{h}}= \\
& \widehat{\mathbf{h}}^{H}\left(\mathbf{U}^{H} \otimes \mathbf{V}^{H}\right)\left(\boldsymbol{\Sigma} \otimes\left(\boldsymbol{\Lambda}+\rho_{\mathrm{d}} \mathbf{I}\right)^{-1}\right)(\mathbf{U} \otimes \mathbf{V}) \widehat{\mathbf{h}} \\
& =\sum_{i, j} \frac{\left|\mathbf{u}_{i}^{H} \mathbf{M} \mathbf{v}_{j}\right|^{2}}{\lambda+\rho_{\mathrm{d}}}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\mathbf{u}_{i}^{T}$ and $\mathbf{v}_{j}^{T}$ are the $i$-th and $j$-th rows of $\mathbf{U}$ and $\mathbf{V}$, respectively. As it turns out from (127), $f\left(\rho_{\mathrm{d}}\right)$ is the Stieltjes transform of a finite measure in $\mathbb{C}^{-}$. Based on [57, Corollary 3.1], it holds that, for any $t>0$,

$$
\left|\frac{1}{1+t f\left(\rho_{\mathrm{d}}\right)}\right| \leqslant 1
$$

## APPENDIX G
## Proof of Lemma 3

We can start the proof by writing the expression in Equation (53) of the paper as below:

$$
\frac{\hat{\mathbf{h}}^{\mathrm{H}} \mathbf{A} \hat{\mathbf{h}}}{\beta-\hat{\mathbf{h}}^{\mathrm{H}} \mathbf{A} \hat{\mathbf{h}}}=\frac{\hat{\mathbf{h}}^{\mathrm{H}} \mathbf{A} \hat{\mathbf{h}}}{\beta}\left(1+\frac{\hat{\mathbf{h}}^{\mathrm{H}} \mathbf{A} \hat{\mathbf{h}}}{\beta-\hat{\mathbf{h}}^{\mathrm{H}} \mathbf{A} \hat{\mathbf{h}}}\right)
$$

We can write the latter equation as

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{\hat{\mathbf{h}}^{\mathrm{H}} \mathbf{A} \hat{\mathbf{h}}}{\beta-\hat{\mathbf{h}}^{\mathrm{H}} \mathbf{A} \hat{\mathbf{h}}}=\frac{\hat{\mathbf{h}}^{\mathrm{H}} \mathbf{A} \hat{\mathbf{h}}}{\beta}+\frac{\hat{\mathbf{h}}^{\mathrm{H}} \mathbf{A} \hat{\mathbf{h}}}{\beta}\left(1-\frac{\hat{\mathbf{h}}^{\mathrm{H}} \mathbf{A} \hat{\mathbf{h}}}{\beta}\right)^{-1} \frac{\hat{\mathbf{h}}^{\mathrm{H}} \mathbf{A} \hat{\mathbf{h}}}{\beta}= \\
& \widehat{\mathbf{h}}^{\mathrm{H}}\left[\frac{\mathbf{A}}{\beta}+\frac{\mathbf{A}}{\beta} \widehat{\mathbf{h}}\left(1-\frac{\hat{\mathbf{h}}^{\mathrm{H}} \mathbf{A} \hat{\mathbf{h}}}{\beta}\right)^{-1} \widehat{\mathbf{h}}^{\mathrm{H}} \frac{\mathbf{A}}{\beta}\right] \widehat{\mathbf{h}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Now, by using Woodbury matrix lemma [60], we can rewrite (130) as

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \widehat{\mathbf{h}}^{\mathrm{H}}\left[\frac{\mathbf{A}}{\beta}+\frac{\mathbf{A}}{\beta} \widehat{\mathbf{h}}\left(1-\frac{\hat{\mathbf{h}}^{\mathrm{H}} \mathbf{A} \hat{\mathbf{h}}}{\beta}\right)^{-1} \widehat{\mathbf{h}}^{\mathrm{H}} \frac{\mathbf{A}}{\beta}\right] \widehat{\mathbf{h}}= \\
& \widehat{\mathbf{h}}^{\mathrm{H}}\left(\mathbf{A}^{-1}-\frac{\hat{\mathbf{h}} \hat{\mathbf{h}}^{\mathrm{H}}}{\beta}\right)^{-1} \widehat{\mathbf{h}}=\beta \widehat{\mathbf{h}}^{\mathrm{H}}\left(\beta \mathbf{A}^{-1}-\widehat{\mathbf{h}} \hat{\mathbf{h}}^{\mathrm{H}}\right)^{-1} \widehat{\mathbf{h}}
\end{aligned}
$$

which proves the result.

## APPENDIX H
## Proof of Proposition 5

Consider a matrix $\widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{k}=\left[\iota^{1}, \ldots, \iota^{N_{r}}\right]^{T} \in \mathbb{C}^{N_{r} \times N_{t}}$ and its vectorized version $\mathbf{z} \triangleq \mathbf{v e c}\left(\widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{k}\right)$. Here, $\iota^{i}, i=1, \ldots, N_{r}$ are

column vectors of size $N_{t} \times 1$ and $\mathbf{z} \in \mathbb{C}^{N_{r} N_{t} \times 1}$ can be partitioned as $\mathbf{z}=\left[\mathbf{z}^{1 T}, \ldots, \mathbf{z}^{N_{r} T}\right]^{T}$, where $\mathbf{z}_{i} \mathrm{~s}$ are of size $N_{t} \times 1$. Due to the definition of operator $\mathcal{A}$ in Equation (21) of the paper, the left-hand side of Equation (53) can be stated as follows:

$$
\mathcal{A}_{k}\left(\mathbf{z z}^{T}\right)=\left[\begin{array}{ccc}
\left\langle\mathbf{z}^{1} \mathbf{z}^{1^{\mathrm{H}}}, \mathbf{C}_{\mathbf{x}_{k}}\right\rangle & \ldots & \left\langle\mathbf{z}^{1} \mathbf{z}^{N_{r} \mathrm{H}}, \mathbf{C}_{\mathbf{x}_{k}}\right\rangle \\
\vdots & \ddots & \vdots \\
\left\langle\mathbf{z}^{N_{r}} \mathbf{z}^{1^{\mathrm{H}}}, \mathbf{C}_{\mathbf{x}_{k}}\right\rangle & \ldots & \left\langle\mathbf{z}^{N_{r}} \mathbf{z}^{N_{r} \mathrm{H}}, \mathbf{C}_{\mathbf{x}_{k}}\right\rangle
\end{array}\right]
$$

By the definition of $\boldsymbol{\operatorname { v e c }}(\cdot)$ operator, we have $\mathbf{z}^{i}=\boldsymbol{\iota}^{i}$. Thus, this leads to

$$
\mathcal{A}_{k}\left(\mathbf{z z}^{T}\right)=\left[\begin{array}{ccc}
\left\langle\boldsymbol{\iota}^{1 T} \mathbf{C}_{\mathbf{x}_{k}} \boldsymbol{\iota}^{1}\right\rangle & \ldots & \left\langle\boldsymbol{\iota}^{1 T} \mathbf{C}_{\mathbf{x}_{k}} \boldsymbol{\iota}^{N_{r}}\right\rangle \\
\vdots & \ddots & \vdots \\
\left\langle\boldsymbol{\iota}^{N_{r} T} \mathbf{C}_{\mathbf{x}_{k}} \boldsymbol{\iota}^{1}\right\rangle & \ldots & \left\langle\boldsymbol{\iota}^{N_{r} T} \mathbf{C}_{\mathbf{x}_{k}} \boldsymbol{\iota}^{N_{r}}\right\rangle
\end{array}\right]=
$$

$$
\widehat{\mathbf{H}} \mathbf{C}_{\mathbf{x}_{k}} \widehat{\mathbf{H}}^{T}
$$

which is exactly the right-hand side of Equation 53.

## APPENDIX I
## Proof of Lemma 2

For any matrices $\mathbf{D} \in \mathbb{C}^{N_{t} N_{r} \times N_{t} N_{r}}$ and $\mathbf{Y} \in \mathbb{C}^{N_{r} \times N_{r}}$, it holds that

$$
\left\langle\mathcal{A}_{k}(\mathbf{D}), \mathbf{Y}\right\rangle=\left\langle\mathbf{D}, \mathcal{A}_{k}^{\mathrm{Adj}} \mathbf{Y}\right\rangle
$$

This leads to

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \sum_{i, j=1}^{N_{r}} Y_{i, j}^{*}\left\langle\mathbf{D}^{i, j}, \mathbf{C}_{\mathbf{x}_{k}}\right\rangle=\sum_{i, j=1}^{N_{r}}\left\langle\mathbf{D}^{i, j}, \mathbf{C}_{\mathbf{x}_{k}} Y_{i, j}\right\rangle= \\
& \left\langle\left[\begin{array}{ccc}
\mathbf{D}_{k}^{(1,1)} & \ldots & \mathbf{D}_{k}^{\left[1, N_{r}\right)} \\
\vdots & \ddots & \ddots \\
\mathbf{D}_{k}^{\left(N_{r}, 1\right)} & \ldots & \mathbf{D}_{k}^{\left(N_{r}, N_{r}\right)}
\end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{ccc}
\mathbf{C}_{\mathbf{x}_{k}} Y_{1,1} & \ldots & \mathbf{C}_{\mathbf{x}_{k}} Y_{1, N_{r}} \\
\vdots & \ddots & \ddots \\
\mathbf{C}_{\mathbf{x}_{k}} Y_{N_{r}, 1} & \ldots & \mathbf{C}_{\mathbf{x}_{k}} Y_{N_{r}, N_{r}}
\end{array}\right]\right\rangle \\
& =\left\langle\mathbf{D}_{k}, \mathbf{C}_{\mathbf{x}_{k}} \otimes \mathbf{Y}\right\rangle
\end{aligned}
$$

where $Y_{i, j}$ is the $(i, j)$ element of $\mathbf{Y}$ and $Y_{i, j}^{*}$ is the complex conjugate of $Y_{i, j}$. This shows that

$$
\mathcal{A}_{k}^{\mathrm{Adj}}(\mathbf{Y})=\mathbf{C}_{\mathbf{x}_{k}} \otimes \mathbf{Y}
$$

abstract:
This work investigates a multi-user, multi-antenna uplink wireless system,
where multiple users transmit signals to a base station. Previous research has
explored the potential for linear growth in spectral efficiency by employing
multiple transmit and receive antennas. This gain depends on the quality of
channel state information and uncorrelated antennas. However, spatial
correlations, arising from closely-spaced antennas, and channel aging effects,
stemming from the difference between the channel at pilot and data time
instances, can substantially counteract these benefits and degrade the
transmission rate, especially in non-stationary environments. To address these
challenges, this work introduces a real-time beamforming framework to
compensate for the spatial correlation effect. A channel estimation scheme is
then developed, leveraging temporal channel correlations and considering mobile
device velocity and antenna spacing. Subsequently, an expression approximating
the average spectral efficiency is obtained, dependent on pilot spacing, pilot
and data powers, and beamforming vectors. By maximizing this expression,
optimal parameters are identified. Numerical results reveal the effectiveness
of the proposed approach compared to prior works. Moreover, optimal pilot
spacing remains unaffected by interference components such as path loss and the
velocity of interference users. The impact of interference components also
diminishes with an increasing number of transmit antennas.
